tEAYdg7Y2xuHpncJqoS7yA.text: If there is zero star I would go for it. Absolutely the worst Chinese restaurant I have ever eaten. How could you eat a juicy dumpling if the sauce is not hot at all? All could the crispy pork belly be as hard as the stone? No, never again!

vQs_g553PZ3-ToR32Xngaw.text: This is in the Wynn, No reservation required. I ordered Shrimp Pad Thai which was delicious

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pad Thai with Shrimp
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu- Pad Thai with Shrimp is what I ordered

pvEaZigb-w2JZ_dHqF5Nsg.text: Had the steamed bbq pork buns and the hot and sour soup.  Soup was hot but very tasty. A little pricey for dim sum but good for LV. Would return here again. Very friendly staff.

wcJL3lawCa3p85qQ8eNgbQ.text: Loved this not so pretentious noodle house at the Wynn.  The soft noodle chow main was excellent and also loved their Mongolian beef.  Good thing I decided to judge for myself instead of listening to some of the yelp reviews.  A little on the pricey side but you're in Vegas, so that's the norm.  You're certainly not going to get pricing like off the strip.  Service was on point, we got our food quickly, and the waiter checked on us often and kept our waters filled.  We pretty much tried all the standard Chinese fair so I can't speak to the dim sum menu.  Will give it another try the next time I stay at the Wynn.

gxP02sVuaEKsG0GnoOTKlQ.text: My in laws can't go more than a day without Asian foods so it made sense why we found ourselves in Red 8 for dinner on our first night in Vegas.   Every item was expected to be overpriced and underwhelming since we were dining in some fancy hotel. That expectation was certainly met. $20 plus for tasteless Penang noodles. $9 for three soupless soup dumplings. Not a single dish was passable in taste (let alone value).   Unless you are stuck like me having to go with whatever your laws were craving - avoid avoid avoid. Save your wallet and your stomach.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Peach and pear Thai tea
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ha gao
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Soup dumplings

7cb-0-ZQ0k01WZ4JPLH5OQ.text: Lettuce wraps and the dim sum were delicious! The Thai coffee was also a nice surprise! Went here for a quick lunch a Dan had a nice experience and meal. Would recommend for a nice lunch!

JcSeWIH0TTMnO7wfbybG8A.text: Good place for lunch. It has all of the usuals albeit with a price tag thats shameless even for Vegas standards. $22 for a side of baby back choy? Is it free range? I'll admit the noodles were good and I would recommend the bbq pork belly. It's also open from lunch all the way to 1am.

dV3n-CYjYyOH3Slf4c8MNA.text: It's all relative.  This four star review is considering that I'm eating at Wynn right by the casino floor.  I've come to learn that almost ALL Vegas restaurants located on premises for all the major resorts are a complete rip off.  That includes getting something as simple as a sandwich.  So if I'm going to pay $20 an entree, I might as well get some decent Chinese food.  The decor is Asian themed and pretty cool.  It's super convenient for those who are gambling or for those like me that are staying at the Wynn and don't want to wander off the resort to grab a meal.  Service was also pretty good for a Vegas restaurant.  Ok let's get to the food.  I ordered Mongolian Beef and Roasted Duck and a bowl of white rice.  They were extremely generous with the amount of beef in the Mongolian beef dish, like there was a lot!  I was impressed.  And their roasted duck was very meaty and crispy.  I was expecting subpar duck but it passed the test.  So overall, it was a pretty good meal.  Let's not talk about value cause there is no value to be had eating on premises of any of the big casinos.    I left Red8 content and enjoying the people that served me, from the waitstaff to the hostess.

Ckk-C4-FNZojaMxrD7V12w.text: Second time eating here and for a place that's been opened as long as it has, the employees can't seem to get out of each other's way. All the food we had was very good nothing exceptional. Drinks were good as well. Service needs significant improvement.

kCCsTnytEZsdFhrygJ35sw.text: I love the dim sum---very authentic!  The service was great and Wynn Resort was beautiful.

H5o7E9x80r_g0euX_2f3CQ.text: The service was great.  Portions and quality were really good.  Hot & Sour soup was typical but the main dishes were above par.  The seared pork belly was really delicious.  Dim sum was of good quality as well.

AAbWxIlAyLGsxg7JO9rZGQ.text: Fantastic customer service, when it came down to one of the people in our party breaking a heel the waiter was down to find glue to help.  But back to the . Loved all of it. I had the udon noodle  and a Thai tea. We rolled out of The Reve and were ready to chow down and Red 8 was a good choice. No complaints in the dinner party.

CieqJQVUud0xOPkXLT4Ngw.text: The best meal by far we had in Las Vegas and we've been to many of the famous restaurants.   Food is fresh, crisp and colorful with great service

v3AfOSPOul46V9dB8gv9DA.text: It was rediculously expensive which one expects, but the food was nothing special. My Beef Chow Mein was light on beef & with onion scallion & peppers the only veggies. The onions were sharp. This was barely a step up from food court Chinese. The cocktail I wanted was $22 so I didn't order it. When paying this for a meal one expects service but what we got was ignored. One drink was refilled and we sat at the table 20 minutes after we had finished eating & arranged our utensils in the empty dishes before spotting our waiter again and requesting the check.  The restaurant was attractive from the outside but our table was in a plain corner so I didn't even get a decent selfie out of it. The food on the plates wasn't photo worthy so I didn't bother. Don't waste your dining dollars here.

bVhfgvNFz4L1c5gCD7OaKA.text: The staff is really nice but this place is way overpriced for the quality of food they serve. The food is super bland with 0 flavor

jAGPKTGrcKUViHdoOlwhnw.text: Chinese place in the Wynn hotel. Very pricey but hey it's Vegas. Service was very good and the food was better than average.   Had the hot and sour soup and sweet and sour chicken. All was good, solid place if price isn't an issue and you don't want to leave the hotel.

viEKqIlayCUQlKC_uXL_5A.text: Noodle soup was horrible. Generic noodles and either a lack of flavor or too much msg in the other. The boba tea was also sitting around for a while so I had to return it.  Belagio's Noodle House is still the place for asian food on the strip.

oIRWF_XMifQ-Shhs8rDRIA.text: I had a business lunch yesterday at Red 8 and really enjoyed it.  We started with the pork potstickers to share and then I followed it up with the chicken with string beans and rice as my entree.  The portion sizes were quite large and the food was quite tasty.  Nicely appointed dining room, professional staff and delicious food = a winning combination for sure!

whQ2G89pndTN5mYEtWIQmQ.text: Had lunch here while staying at the Wynn. They have a wonderful dim sum menu. We had pan fried pork dumplings, chicken and pork lettuce wraps, shrimp and chicken shu mai, BBQ pork buns, vegetable spring rolls. Everything was absolutely delicious.   They have a whole section of Hong Kong barbecue as well as some Thai and Vietnamese dishes.  Not a typical "American" Chinese food menu so don't expect a lot of those typical combination type dishes here - excellent.

KuGPv3WuE30kt2ee2AxS-Q.text: 2.5 stars First time i ate here 2-3 years ago, I really loved it. Ordered identical items this trip; the combo fried rice, and pad-thai. Didnt like them at all; in fact pick-up-dixx makes a better both, at an 80% discount. $85 bucks for one tsingtao (damn love that chinese beer), diet coke, 2 entrees mentioned, and a spring roll appetizzy (decent) Ridiculous prices, even for the Wynn. And mind you, probably ate the lowest priced entrees on the menu, or darn near the bottom. Not from cheapness, I like those items (well, LIKED.) Waited 40 minutes when told about a 20-25 minute wait. They dont take reservations and are a bit disorganized in that dept. Service was attentive, just disappointed quality of items has gone downhill (add to the list in this city) If you love panda express then this place will flip your untasty noodle.

W5wMWXlHj5vF4Igp3XUcZw.text: Service- always not too busy here. We ate around 8-ish at night. The food and drinks came really fast!  Food- spicy beef chow fun looking dish- this was really delicious! crispy yellow noodle with veggies and chicken- this one was less flavorful, but the crispy noodle was yummy  Drinks- we got 1 drink each weren't too alcohol-ish  Bill was about $80-ish

s17AfIE_GP8-jLuI5NuU-Q.text: I see why most guests post a 3-star review; Very simple: great decor, fun food, bad service and no bar.   We hope for improvement in this amazing hotel.   Thanks in advace, Manager.

SocjmFHN43TYKeJiHw3QyQ.text: Took a friend there for dinner as were just wandering around. Walked in without reservation around 8:00p on a Saturday and they were very accommodating.  Were seated and did not have anyone address our table for at least 5-8 mins, food was slow coming out, but very tasty.  Felt the table arrangement was too close as we could hear everything the next table was saying and they were't loud.  I would recommend,but for a casual dinner.  This is not one for a romantic setting if that is what you want.

9yjgCm7kgvFDrg9HeWOfnA.text: Went for some dimsum on a Saturday morning. Not busy, so there were plenty of tables available.  Very cool decorations. Service is prompt.   The dimsum takes a bit to come out, but that's because it's made to order. Sip on some nice hot tea while you wait. When it arrived the dimsum was very tasty. We had shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, stuffed mushrooms, sticky rice, fried rice and some other good dishes.  Although a bit pricey it's worth it for a nice tasting meal in a nice place.

IE0zDAn4OB3fCOMk2Ethew.text: This place isn't that bad ....I ordered a seafood fried rice and really enjoyed the flavor. When we went my friend unfortunately got sick from the wonton soup but she does have a sensitive stomach. ( but the days prior to this we ate at 3 different buffets and found it ironic she got sick from the nice restaurant and not the buffets) If you wanted to splurge on a nice meal I do feel like this restaurant would be a waste. I think it's really really overpriced chinese food. You could get A LOT better from the chinatown in LV for a lot less. I personally won't be going back.

Kcv7gnTI-SMB8XRg8qa7jg.text: Came here for a quick bite.  Awesome egg noodle soup (think it was a red 8 special) compared to other places on the strip. I don't like Asia Noodle inside of Venetian because their broth is too bland. Dumplings in the noodle soup was sooo flavorful and packed with various ingredients.  Hargow was up to par.  Authentic taste. Cannot compare at ALL to Panda Express so I'm not sure why some reviewers were comparing it to Panda.  Prices are reasonable for Vegas and being inside Wynn

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Fr8GJIfH4K9r1GHTg-qj_w.text: Whenever my extended family stays at the Wynn (more than I'd like to admit...), we always enjoy a meal at Red 8. The Asian food here is really yummy and it's fun to look out the "window" into the Wynn casino.  Last time, I enjoyed one of the most delicious cocktails I'd ever tasted. I ordered fresh watermelon juice with vodka and it was SO good!!! I always fill up on the family-style Asian food too and then head into the Casino to work off the food ;)  Red 8 is accommodating for young children and not as expensive as one would expect of a restaurant in the Wynn.

DV2yBT3Cka4TbXpn8lIZ4w.text: The Mongolian Beef was very good and the service was super fast. The wonton soup was just "ok".  It was over priced, which is typical of all these so called "fancy" hotel restaurants.

heqKbH97jkDjwGQ-gWB8nQ.text: Authentic Cantonese cuisine and decorated very nicely. The chairs aren't that comfortable but the Kung pap chicken was vey good.  Wait staff was friendly and they speak Cantonese.

WpYJZXqdFtKXlwUx3lrc_A.text: Steve Wynn, you should be ashamed that you let people put this crap in peoples' mouths.   Where to start... It's Christmas and like tradition we had to get Chinese food. We've been to Wazuzu before and love it, but tried Red 8 as a change of pace.  Positively, we were able to call from our room to put our name on the 1.5 hour waitlist (no reservations). We came down an hour later and were seated 10 min after that.   It just went downhill from there. We asked our waiter how big the portions were, and his reply was "a good size." Wtf. I said "this big?" (Gesturing with my hands) or "this big?" (Gesturing with my hands)... "Yeah, that big," he said. Thanks for the non-clarification.   We also wanted to order one of the specialty "Wynn Macau" noodles, but with chicken instead of pork. We were told that wasn't allowed, as the soups are "pre-made." That should've been sign #1.   We ended up ordering the following: -Pork wontons in chili oil: pork had NO taste, and even if it did, the overly spicy and oily sauce would way overpower it anyway disgusting.  -Marinated chicken with supreme soy sauce: this was kind of like Peking duck, but chicken and way more disgusting. And cold (remember: everything is premade). The chicken was kind of fatty, which is ok because of the style they were going for, but it had no taste whatsoever.  -noodles with beef in soya sauce: noodles were crispy, but the sauce had no taste. Beef was also cold and stringy and was of poor quality.   The guys sitting next to us got their food and were staring at it. We looked over and started laughing. "If the shrimp were any smaller they'd be dust mites," he told us.  Enough said.   all in all, this place is disgusting on all levels. Service and food. Now I'm from NY, so I know my Chinese food and this ain't it.   We'll be going back to Wazuzu tomorrow, but first we're having a real dinner. Hopefully our second dinner at Zooza Crackers is better.   NOTE: our table-neighbors told us about this great hidden pizza place in Cosmo. We'll check out that out tomorrow.

oveBEaR6ZYBd1TYPt7lmvQ.text: The food was done well, service was professional and friendly.  For an Asian experience in Vegas it's worth the trip to the Wynn.  Try the dumplings, walnut shrimp and beef noodle soup!

bTOehiv3a_nNbE4LAfVmwA.text: Out of all the restaurants in the Wynn this is hands down my favorite restaurant. It is casual and all the dishes are superb. As a starter I love their hot and sour soup like no other! And as the entree I can order the spicy soft shell crab all day.  There is no going wrong with this restaurant. Wish I was in Vegas now this is definitely where I would be for lunch even for dinner!  Sometimes the wait can be annoying especially when you are hungry but its worth the wait in my opinion.

HGgl4rI2oCI6ofCp_JeVvA.text: Partner and I ate here while staying at the Wynn - Encore. We walked in around 630-700 (first come first serve kind of place) and was able to get a table after about a 30 min wait. We shared the duck appetizer which was good. He had the duck and I had the walnut prawns. Both dishes were quite good. Great food, good service, and not super expensive. The tables are a little too close together for my taste but I am sure we could have found a more intimate setting in another restaurant as this is a semi-casual dining option.

HH3kdP1DB384HIBog-UKAQ.text: Needed boba when I was staying on the strip. Totally worth the $25 spent on the cab fare.

CuhLOgo-YB31T548O5UYZg.text: Seriously?! Dress code for chinese food? I just came to get a bite to eat and they refused service. Price is high for chinese food and no matter what they try to do its still just regular chinese food.

fYSjao98TizDbgbPDFK11w.text: I'm not sure why this place only has 3 stars?!?!  This is a must go when I'm at Wynn!!! Always go for lunch but it's overall high quality Chinese food!!!  I've ordered everything from the dim sums, congee, braised abalone, soup noodles, sweet and sour pork, crispy noodles, house fried rice... And many more!!!  My favs are the abalone congee, crispy fried noodles, fried rice, pot stickers, shiu Mai, sweet and sour pork and their noodle soup. Pretty much everything I've tried is great! Also the chicken items are always soooo tender.   Service is great ( most of the time) the hosts are always very nice!!  Better than wing lei. DO NOT go there!!!

vwL75JMBcQjthiUUyw3fNw.text: Came here for lunch right when they opened so no wait.  Portions are pretty small so if you plan on sharing this is probably not the right place.  I had halibat and it was good.  Coocked right and not too salty.   Service was good and we were in and out in about an hour.  A little pricey for lunch.

Ms8ZaPMJkRUMFMspgr6oUw.text: Friday the 13 at 7:00 pm had dinner with my Church party of 18 pax, went before to let them know we would like to have a table. I called a week before to let them know I'll be bringing in that group and surely it was promising. It was so disappointing because first of all Crystal the MOD was very unfriendly not helpful and very cold to us. My group was elderly so when we sat down some of them couldn't sit on the High Stool Chairs. Crystal did not do anything just let us figure out by ourselves. It took us a good fifteen minutes to sit down just to be comfortable. Then we have Joe out server took our order. After dinner he gave the check to one of group and as he said he could separate the check 4 ways. He left us alone let us figure out the check 3 ways. Then I ask for a manager again and still no help from her at All. I ask her to calculate the check by the numbers I've mark and surely no cares. I've told her that the service was Bad and had to ask for everything. She had let one server to take of party of 18 people and still took tables f on his section. To the Hotel Operations and Director of  Restaurants Crystal don't care about people how to give 5 star service. I've canceled a reservation at Anthony's just to come and eat at Red 8. Sorry but I have to give my rant because it bothers me any my church. They added gratuity of 18% and a tax fee for large parties. I don't mind if the service was great but no service at All. Crystal you need an assessment of how you take care of your guest. Anonymous. But I will be making a call to the Hotel operations and the FB Director.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. This our group

lCzOPMzsNHbzTQHH4PFxsQ.text: Urhhh, I am not coming aback again. The food is just urhhhhhhhh

CUV0Xt2CCsAoFhyjiKSIKg.text: I've been here twice.  First time I had dim sum which was quite good, the second time I had some kind of chicken and mushroom soup and noodle dish that was mediocre at best.  Service is decent, decor is nice. But honestly, for Asian food at around this price point at the Wynn/Encore, I'd rather go to Wazuzu.

B-kFZ_398KL_tLRXQ6JnRQ.text: I love staying at the Wynn.  I had been looking forward to eating here after running out of time on the last 3 stays. I was really underwhelmed. The Wynn has many other better options.  This is some of the least authentic Chinese food I have ever had.  The Panda Express at a shopping mall food court is more authentic than this.  The Dan Dan noodles was cheap ramen with a squirt of bottled Hosin sauce and Sriracha. This would be like ordering spaghetti marinara and getting ketchup for the tomato sauce.   The chicken satay was deep fried not grilled. Yuck., How do you think a sirloin steak would taste is you decided to deep fry it instead of putting it on a broiler.  Head over to the Encore side and try the asian restaurant there, it is way better.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Probably the worst Dan Dan Noodles I have ever had. Ramen with peanuts, a squirt of Hosin  sauce and Sriracha. Really bad.
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp  with candied walnuts and mayo - not great
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Deep fried not grilled chicken satay - pretty bad

k8cXiHlZn5DJTM5zVcIwLw.text: I was super excited to eat here at first but the service was terrible. I work in food service at a bistro and give better service than that. We got put in a corner area and my group felt neglected the whole time. The food took forever to come, the waiter came by and didn't even fill up our drinks we had to ask several times for more drinks. He also took forever to ask how our food was. We sat there waiting 15+ minutes after we were done eating for our waiter to come back so we could ask for our checks. We got sick of waiting and eventually got up and asked for our checks and the staff seemed irritated by that but we were sick of waiting for someone to show up. After asking for our checks we still waited 10+ minutes to even receive them and another 10 to get our cards back. We only had a group of 5, and were younger so maybe they thought they could neglect us and treat us like we weren't there. WORST WORST WORST service I've had, I get better service at the McDonald's drive through.

yf3TBEe0Q3hfS0Ou7D1lOQ.text: We dine here frequently as we are always visiting Vegas. This is one of my favorite restaurants but I had a bad experience here today- I have a severe allergy to onions and the waiter took the order correctly but the chef decided to cook my food with onions and what looks like tried to pick them out but they were still there. Long story short my throat started closing and I found a few of the onions in my beef hor fun. I requested for the manager to come so I could address the issue- was that a mistake. She looked at me like I was in the wrong and the waiter even said the kitchen made a mistake. Nonetheless she didn't apologize- nor try to remedy the issue, I hope they don't make this a common practice because I will stop coming here if this is the direction they are going to treat repeat clients.

Bv3NwEtIPjlcaTdx3QvB4A.text: I found Red 8 to be a fantastic experience from greeting to paying the bill. The food was absolutely fantastic. Especially enjoyed the wasabi shrimp.  The service was warm and efficient.  And it isn't crazy priced. I would suggest that anyone looking to enjoy multiple fantastic choices of Asian style cuisine must eat at Red 8. And don't bother with a reservation, they don't take them. Just go in and they seat you. Great job chef and staff of Red 8.  We will be back again and again.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Scallops. Fantastic with the mango sauce.
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wasabi shrimp. Wow. Unbelievably good.

60hczwqstm6Vy9YBmcLgHg.text: Really nice vegan dishes! I mean...aside from everything in the vegetarian section of the menu being either a) already vegan or b) capable of altered to be vegan, they even had vegan dim sum!!! Dim sum is the thing I missed the most since going vegan tbh. This places is amazing. It's quite pricey, but I'd rather throw my money down here and eat a bunch of vegan dim sum to satisfy my cravings, rather than a giant Vegas buffet where I can eat like 4 things. They use a lot of gardein "meats" as dumpling filler and also for their "chicken" wraps. Really delicious!  The best part is, this restaurant has awesome noodles soups too, so my meat-eating family can enjoy a meal with me in the same place! My dad, who is just about the most judgmental eater in the world, genuinely liked their beef brisket soup with egg noodles. He raved about how satisfied he was and then got the fresh mango sago for dessert (which he also gobbled up in record time). Mom loved the wonton soup with egg noodles, and my husband got the stir fried noodles with beef, which he cleaned the plate of.  The only thing that was weak was the black sesame porridge. Definitely not sweet enough, which is a shame because it's one of my favorites! Service is meh, but we came for the food and we left quite satisfied!

kahi6nZN44-6HwRnfpYnGw.text: I am not a fan of Chinese food what so ever.. But... I was dining with my boyfriend and his friends so I took a chance on this place with an open mind.  Let's just say the food was excellent ! Very well prepared and delicious ! I didn't feel like i was jacked up on sodium after i left like most places.   The place is really pretty too. We sat in a private round room/area and was really nice. The staff was pleasant too. :)

BPa-oa07kKz3x4WCbv1g2w.text: Minus one star for service.  The Wynn did a great job on decor for this place, it's really red. It has a super authentic feel with all Chinese workers. However, the prices are somewhat high for asian food, but not too high where it was ridiculous. The quality is definitely up their.  Egg rolls- skip it. It was wet and soggy inside. Orange chicken- Loved this dish. I would come back for it. Make sure you get this. Beef Chowfun- another solid dish rice- it's rice, you cannot mess this one up.  The 3 dishes I chose paired beautifully together.   Yes the prices are higher then normal, you are in the Wynn after all.

BoRpev_-YXRIl0YMTGHFyA.text: Real good and authentic Cantonese food and dim sum with high quality like back home The best Cantonese food among all Vegas theme hotels

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pumpkins  shrimp bun beef pad Thai

pKotCD4y6FWgChP73RtTqg.text: Some family members and I stopped at Red 8 for lunch last week while we were visiting the Wynn. We ordered several dishes, i.e. crispy shrimp with walnuts, veg. Fried brown rice, spring rolls, Kung Pao shrimp, and I believe 2 others. The food was  tasty and presented well; we really liked it! The service was excellent and the restaurant was clean and Tastefully decorated. Yes, it's on the expensive side but prices are in line with similar restaurants in the resorts, so don't let that deter you from visiting Red 8. I recommend anyone who is visiting the Wynn and wants some good Asian food, to visit Red 8 for some good food and good service!

LOh9AupPwjyvEeZHp3oXTA.text: I'd have to rate this place 2.5 stars. Food is mediocre at best, doesn't match its price point. My biggest disappointment would be their wait staff.

ayT10fkGIi_GOPOoRvIp2w.text: We were walking around the Wynn which though beautiful and stunning, it had a weird vibe. It was really empty while we were there, which is strange because it was a holiday weekend. We decided to have dinner there and Red 8 seemed like a good option (and one of the more affordable ones). We went up to the host and asked for a table for 2 and were so surprised to hear that it was a 20 minute wait. The hotel was so quiet and empty! We played a few slots to kill some time and when we went back only 15 minutes later, we were seated right away ... in a half empty restaurant! That already had my eyes rolling and then the rest of the night seemed to drag. It took awhile to get our order placed, waited some more for the food to come out, our waiter seemed to disappear when we wanted our check and we had to ask 2 different people before it finally came. It just didn't have the service I'd expect from a nicer hotel. And I really don't know what they were trying to prove with the wait-time when the restaurant was half empty.  Now as for the food, I had the dan dan noodles with pork which was just OK. The portion could have been bigger (compared to my husband's similar-to-spicy-Thai basil noodles which was a large portion) and I barely had any pork.

Nh5_S8L5-k9PQ7E7i11Z2g.text: Ended up going here at the request of a customer and found it to be average. The decor was wonderful. The staff was attentive. But the food was bland. One of the Chinese places near my house has food that is 10x better and 1/10 the price.

Pe9csRKGhxPmfHsuMdHM1Q.text: Been here many times and always enjoy their sliced beef with egg congee, shrimp and ground pork wontons and crispy roasted pork belly. I would say the food is pretty authentic but the price is kinda steep.

sEk3PyllKzxN4J3Y87XfVw.text: I love this place but I do have to say, they need to work on one thing. I ordered vegetables with tofu and noodles with cashews. By the time she "added on" everything, the dish ended up being MORE than my friends BEEF dish. Are you kidding me???? It is vegetables and tofu for goodness sake. They didn't even have to kill a damn cow. My dish cost $25 and his was $21.  Ridiculous. Please work on this Red 8 or I won't be able to come  back.

XQTzPRaRk3QEdkt2YGrZdQ.text: Decent food offering a menu that caters to both hardcore Hong Kong eaters as well as those with a more western palate, all at reasonable prices (considering that it's Las Vegas...at WYNN).  Why then four stars instead of five?  The seats at the tables have the distinction of being the most uncomfortable that I have ever sat in. I have dined at Red 8 twice, and both times I could not help but notice how narrow the seat is in between the wood stalks that make up the back portion of the chair. These sentiments are shared with everybody that I dined with. So terrible, are the design of these chairs, that I would seriously have to consider dining here again and endure an hour of suffering. Management, please, for the love of Confucius, considering replacing the chairs.

FA7B7aaIxOwwkDflE94OdQ.text: Just OK. Decent prices for a sit-down Vegas meal. Swanky, comfortable surroundings.  Food was nothing special ... actually, quite a bit of it was tasteless.  I liked my steamed BBQ pork buns, but I've had better at dive-y, mom & pop places. My cashew chicken might as well have been made from a frozen dinner.  The food was certainly fresh ... just totally nothing special. Go somewhere else. Expected better from the Wynn.

1uncYM1nTZs7t11Gw2aWyQ.text: Our party of 7 dined here on one of the nights in Vegas because we were at the Wynn and wanted Asian food.  Red 8 is a casual Asian fusion restaurant. You will find Vietnamese, Cantonese, Thai, and Indian here. We ordered a number of dishes and did family style.   Here's what we ordered:   Beef Chow Fun Wonton Soup (2 orders) Shrimp Walnut Kung Pao Shrimp Mongolian Beef  We didn't have high expectations or anything, BUT all the dishes were terrible. It was bland and had no flavor. On top of that, each dish was tiny portions and double the price of the average Chinese restaurant. Service was not great either. I wish he was more attentive.   Our bill was $150--no drinks with gratuity included. NEVER again.

cuvLtNHx_tuqjiKUvTxGvA.text: Came for dinner with my mom on a Tuesday night without reservations and waited maybe about 10 minutes before being seated.  Red 8 is a nice place to eat that isn't too upscale or toocasual.  There's a lot of choices from dim sum, to various noodle and rice dishes and dumplings.  Red 8 serves pretty tasty Chinese food, better than some of the Chinese places at other hotels nearby.  My only downfall to the place was probably the wait time for the food.  I ordered a hot and sour soup, the portion was quite small.. I thought it was quite delicious but my mom thought it was too salty.  Next we had what was supposed to be the pork and shrimp dumplings..but I think they sent us pork dumplings ( I couldn't taste any shrimp in it).  The dumplings were steamed and were quite flavorful..although a bit rich, which is why I was wanting the shrimp and pork dumplings. It came in an order of 3, so after me and my mom each had one, I felt bad letting the waiter know the order was wrong.  We also ordered the Beef Hor Fun (in soy sauce) to share.  This was quite a large and filling portion with nice sized pieces of beef.  Lastly we had the Vegan Tofu Shiitake.  Pieces of tofu, veggie and shiitake mushrooms, exactly what I was craving for.  Everything was pretty good, I'm usually not a fan of Chinese food, but I thought that Red 8 had good variety, ambiance and Chinese fare.

ud6vSwlySBoMr4T1AfDp9A.text: Sorry I mixed up Wazuzu and Red 8; Here my new review:  I was there in December 2016. I went for lunch alone while hubby was working.   I had dim sum. As a vegan it was so much fun to have choices. The waiter I had was an older gentleman and he truly brought me back to last trip to China. This was heavenly. I also had a nice tea with my dim sum. It was very laid back and took my time to enjoy my meal. The food was very very good. The server was very kind and he was very patient with other diners! I can't judge the price because as a Vegan this kind of options are rare so for me it was a lunch that was more than what I would usually choose money wise, but the level of the quality and presentation and taste was a real gem. In the end, it cost me around $40. But it was such a nice experience that I felt that it was worth it. Not every day, but surely every time I am in Vegas, I will go to have a lunch at Red 8.

nZSmoSazVksjfOpQk7dS9A.text: i enjoyed the experience at red 8 which was one of the best restaurant experience. Dimsum tatsted great and chestnut shrimp was very delicious.  what i liked the most was the servers and the hosts are very friendly and seem to enjoy what they were doing.  but the weakness was that the price was little overated compare to other locan chinese restaurants

04apmNU3LHsiWracl7piRg.text: Stumbled across this place almost accidentally -- what an unexpected treasure. Lovely room with a lovely ambience. You can hold a conversation!  We took some gambles with unfamiliar menu items and our boldness paid off for the most part. I loved the pan-fried pumpkin dumplings, and the Bao were as good as what we eat on Sunday mornings in Monterrey Park. Noodle dishes were excellent and served very beautifully. This is an extensive menu requiring some leaps of faith and bit of the explorer's instinct. We got lucky and had a simply wonderful  meal.

rGUHpatGkllzjNi6TDWwqw.text: I'm surprised to see these many Chinese eateries popped up in Vegas since my last visit in 2010. We wanted to try WING LEI in Wynn, however it was closed until late December, so we ended up here in Red 8.   It's a casual Chinese eatery offering traditional Chinese dishes with a little bit American twist. I liked the red themed decor which symbolized fortune in Chinese culture.  I ordered the Tofu Salty Fish pot and my wife ordered the Tomato Based Shrimp noodle soup. It's a smaller portion than what you might expect, but it is just the right size for us. The food is very well prepared. The jumbo shrimp is very sweet and has that crunchy bite only the freshest shrimp can bring. The tomato base soup is very rich and has a great aroma. The tofu is very smooth and delicate, and the overall flavor of my Tofu Salty Fish pot pairs very well with white rice.  I would recommend this place to anyone who is willing to try something different than the Vegas buffets and Steakhouses. For the price of one upscale buffet, two person would be experiencing great Chinese cuisine in a cozy and relaxed atmosphere.

ipdY5yhqqi_yhtKfgyB2tQ.text: Real rating- 3.5, extra half star for really great service!  Red 8 provides a nice ambience without crazy Vegas hotel dining prices. Don't get me wrong, it is by no means cheap but it isn't very expensive either.   The food is not extraordinary but good enough, even though one of the dishes was really salty.   Overall, there aren't many decently priced, nice places for Chinese food on the strip so Red 8 is a good option if Chinese is what you're looking for.

gKXzCN8t3kRNiY1d_Kgy0w.text: Ok food, good atmosphere.  Went here with a large group and had the fried brown rice, which was ok.  This dish as well as other dishes was not very spicy.  The service was good.  I wish they had slightly better chopsticks though, given the effort put into the rest of their ambiance.

aMu6okPyRVVGe8ar-LsTYw.text: Ok people!! This is my second times come in for dinner!! I just love love the food and the price here!! Trust me!! They are aways aways busy!! ( as u can see when u walk in ) u got to try the thai tea here!! It's sooo good!! Not to sweet and u can and boba if u like!! U just can't beat it!!

wC9cbtO8gcgaajaThSJC0Q.text: You can't go wrong for a great casual Thai meal, and you can walk in!

gKK7wGER3qvZvg6xXmtGCg.text: Ok i have to be honest I am shocked that this level of quality is served at a steve wynn resort. The meal was comped but seriously this place was horrible. Panda express would be an improvement over this place. The bill was 130 for one person for lunch. Of course i had leftovers to take to pops but I felt like he might feel as though I was trying to poison him. I ordered the cantonese pot stickers to start. You could do better in the frozen section at costco. Next up I opted for the upgraded beef dish which is served table side on a sizzling platter it was like pepper beef sirloin or something like that. Really boring dish no imagination. was funny when i was ordering the waiter suggests i upgrade even further to kobe beef,I said well you probably wont get the benefit if its covered in a sauce,he says I will,even though i had a 200 comp and would not have had to pay for it I didn't do it. I asked him how much would it cost ,he says let me look on the menu,after we look together he cant find it he estimates it to cost around 90 dollars,like i said it would have been comped but it seemed too egregious to me. Next I ordered the sweet and sour chicken,total crap again you could do much better at panda express or costco. And lastly I ordered a bbq pork and shrimp combo fried rice,this was the best dish of all and I suspect that it is served regularly at the CCDC on fried crap night. In conclusion im glad i had  the comp but i still had to tip for 20 bucks ,its not the servers fault so i always take care of them. The server was very nice actually. Steve must be losing his taste as well as his vision because anyone who would rate this anything but touristy garbage food is on the payroll.

qiNTRfz6hZVk5DBoI9YZ3g.text: Red 8 is an amazing authentic Chinese restaurant with great ambiance. My husband and I stay at the Wynn 2-3 times per year and always have a meal at Red 8 when we are in town. Great service, extensive menu, late hours...I would recommend you check it out!

leIIFgGmrPZoteAfGlq4sQ.text: Not a bad choice for a very late dinner and limited options. The food is solid and the drinks are pretty good. We tried a couple of things including the squid dish. The roasted pork belly is the only dish I'd say is really fantastic; crispy and delicious. The rest of the food was just average. The decor is cute but given that this is inside the Wynn, I wouldn't have expected bad decor.

848jhyIsljLMIeMsXpmu7g.text: ehh it wasn't the best but not the worst. I had the monoglian beef

f1tGeScOXngqZmunzqTrWw.text: The food was almost amazing, the service was the worst I have ever had, it took them over 20-30 min to bring water, then when we asked for a condiment sauce by the time it came the food was cold : (  Please work on the staff service please!!!

TGQN24D58RcNPCLtmw-Tyw.text: Red 8 is a Chinese restaurant in the Wynn Hotel.  I ordered Kung Pao chicken, which was very tasty, although not as spicy as it might have been.  The portion was a good size and the ingredients were fresh. I gave Red 8 a 3 star mainly because it was so overpriced - $19 for a dish that costs $9 anywhere else is problematic.

CohAYa8GyWJfSXh4RAs0sg.text: I have been dying to come here during my last few visits to the Wynn. There is a long wait for Red 8 but the food is good and the prices aren't bad. It is an above average Chinese restaurant as far as quality and ambiance.

25EjqEGqCvA2ERle9eS7Ow.text: So we went back to Red 8 this past weekend on Saturday night after being invited back from the Red 8 team. This dining experience was fantastic. The service was outstanding and the food was superb. The Sweet and Sour Chicken, Chicken Fried Rice, Kung Pau Chicken and Spring rolls were amazing. We shared the food it was perfect. I wish i could remember the servers name as he was very attentive and the waiter assistants were helpful as well. Thanks for a great Saturday Night Dinner before a night out on the town.  We will go back for sure...

h6UQVuwvnLZ7VFvwvZEBww.text: Just average service.  Made us (2people) wait 15 mins for a seat when plenty of seats were open.   Limited dim sum many so we ordered entrees.   Spring rolls were a little burned.

OnpKG2UIOIydn9fap5B0gA.text: Red 8 is easily my most favorite Chinese restaurant on the Vegas Strip. Although their prices might be a bit pricey, their signature dishes are amazing! My husband and I always love to order their Roasted Duck. Their duck meat is tender and they also provide sweet dipping sauce to complement the taste. You can easily finish the plate between two people. One of their signature dishes is Baby Bok Choy covered in Scallop Sauce. In real life, I do not like to eat scallop. But for some reason, their special scallop sauce brings out the best flavor in baby bok choy. It was so delicious that we finished the entire plate. I also like to order their Rice Congee with Pork and Preserved Egg. They serve it in a huge bowl, and it's enough for several servings.  My husband also ordered noodles from their special noodle menu. You can pick the noodle of your choice as well as the meat. He picked egg noodle with chicken and mushroom. It was very filling and delicious from what he told me. I always have a craving for Red 8 ever since the Wynn first opened up. It's definitely worth a visit if you feel like great Chinese on the Vegas Strip.

rKtermQKYFG5Tx699JiUpQ.text: We had pork buns, sweet and sour chicken, and black bean sauteed spare ribs and they were all good.  I like the ambiance and location, but I was hoping to be wow'd more by the taste at the prices.  The portions were good size and it came with rice.  It gets a 3.5 stars rounding down since I wouldn't rush back.

qhJW4uGfZKnYijN3xChD_Q.text: This is probably the best bargain in the Wynn. Ironically, I've stayed here a couple of times, but did not try Red 8 until this trip when I stayed at the Mandarin. Go figure.  Steve Wynn's Macau location gets some love here on the menu in the form of some nice noodle dishes. Standouts for me were the cold chicken and jellyfish appetizer, and my Traditional Beijing Pork Noodles. I like that this place isn't stuffy, just good food at reasonable (for Vegas) prices.

VziKh3f22ZIVtnXS9wzWCA.text: This is why I like Vegas. You can charge upscale prices for your most standard hawker style food. You just have to get some nice chairs and a couple of plush looking sofas and make it look all exquisitely Asian.  Add a couple of Delft type vases, then you're all set.  Honestly, the food is pretty tasty. I got the clay pot with chicken, salted fish, minced pork, and tofu with rice. It had good flavoring to it and the tofu was quite silky. Costed me about $16. Not ridiculous, I'll admit. My husband ordered Dumpling Noodle Soup and it was about $15. Nothing extraordinary.   The service wasn't exceptional. They actually didn't seem to want to be there. I think they're just tired of all the snobbish visitors, honestly. So, we didn't feel the love there ;P.   Overall, we wouldn't go back unless we were stuck at the Wynn and we're starving AND it's the only restaurant that's still open.   Two stars for tasty food and that's it.

ziNJk2UGzCoQ78-rYlQeZA.text: small portion dishes, packed w/ people and super slow service.  food was okay, I liked my Singapore fried rice noodle.  for the price they charge, I say so somewhere else ~

7pKo6HbcK_4b198b2LPCMQ.text: I was happy to read ahead of time that Steve Wynn who is now vegan,  has vegan options at each of his restaurants.  I wanted to try one of them, Red 8 was the first one I passed while walking through the hotel, so I decided to try it.  I was thinking of either the lettuce wraps or the Gardein "chicken" with broccoli, carrots,celery and cashews in a ginger sauce.(actually I substituted the mushrooms for broccoli which they had no problem doing) The waiter told me the wraps are pretty small and more of an appetizer and to go with the other, so I did. It was very flavorful! I liked it a lot even though it was $18..they sell Gardein in Whole Foods and other health food stores, so it's not something they make on their own in the restaurant so it seems a bit pricey for it, but the food was really well cooked,the vegetables were so good and fresh. The waiter was very friendly too. I'd recommend coming here.

tn8PQ5CXNv40tn6uRE9apg.text: I've eaten at Red 8 three times now. This place is awesome. It's so difficult to find a restaurant that serves Kong Xin Cai! Since this is my favorite vegetable (the hollow-heart vegetable) I always get that. On the menu it's labeled as "wok-fried water spinach, preserved bean curd." So that's what you're looking for.  This most recent time I had the curried Singapore rice vermicelli with shredded pork, shrimp, egg, and bean sprouts, as well as the wok-fried chicken in black bean sauce. I always share family style with a coworker. The bill is always $70 something, and I always use the corporate credit card. It's one of the few "casual dining" options at Wynn, and still obscenely expensive. It's all relative I guess. This place is relatively shabby as far as Wynn dining options go, only because they do not provide complimentary royal princesses from third-world vassal countries to massage your hands with slightly heated polished rubies every time you have to strain your fingers by cleaning your pasty pasty mouth with a wetnap made of a thousand dollar bill infused with a mixture of 1938 Clos du Mesnil champagne and the sweat of a virgin king cobra. If you look at it that way, this place is a shithole.  I will continue to eat here anytime I get the chance.

vpEJVc17osHGJd5gsGJLhw.text: I really enjoyed this resturant, we had great service and yummy food. my husband thought a bit pricey, but I loved it so much, no left over's!

xsMtycv9IujImd8idMT5wA.text: Food was good.  Prices are typical Vegas...Expensive.  Hey, you're in the Wynn Resort...what do you expect?  When you're losing too much at the table, take a break and come here for a descent quick meal.  Those satays are mighty tasty!

bvp2RQUEEtQMK7Cx0-SKrw.text: $3 for a bowl of rice!!! Yikes! Late night dining options at the Wynn were limited and led us to this place. We ordered bbq pork, bbq duck and two bowls of rice $45. OMG! Sam Woo bbq we could of eaten the same thing for like $15 and it would of tasted better. I don't mind paying for a good meal, but being over charged for mediocre food just makes me pout. The server was an automaton, no smile, no energy, no emotion. Sad, Wynn, Sad! I just wanted a tasty late night dinner but no go at Red 8.

1ncAjv-6Te7OPYDSpUsdtw.text: Steve Wynn imported the best  chefs to staff his various restaurants in the Wynn Hotel. Have not tried them all, but the dim sum and pad thai at Red 8 are memorable and worth many visits.

jSe_faimUDoKqIkZgLKFfQ.text: I came here wanting to eat Dim sum for brunch. Nothing really stood out to me to be different from any other dim sum place that I've gone to. However I did love their coconut pudding for dessert. The dishes are somewhat overpriced, but what do you expect, IT'S VEGAS! The service was always great though, I would recommend making a reservation because there is the occasional line that I've run into a couple of times. I would say that the portions are somewhat small so if you expect to be stuffed after your meal, you might want to look to eat somewhere else. Overall, my experience at RED 8 has never failed. What I expected is what i got. Nothing bad, but nothing like oh this restaurant deserves the James Beard Award.

ob1OyrMweGVaFURunprEWw.text: Had some soy chicken, it wasn't very good.  Chicken came out a little cold and flavorless.  The other guys seemed to enjoy their meals.

a3Ku31k8-_qGJUcvYeDAEw.text: Ok the food and service not so memorable. But it is a decent place to go to after the Le Reve show at the Wynn .  I gave it an extra star for the low key atmosphere because really sometimes Vegas can be too much and this place was open late but doesnt turn into some loud bar ! We found the service to be below average and certainly not what you'd expect at the Wynn. The food itself ranged from bland to too spicy. The best thing was the pork buns and the Coke.

45nHIlpsOd2Huis5ZzfIjg.text: Better than the other places we ate at on the Wynn/Encore property and that's not saying a whole lot. Service was efficient, place is attractive, menu good. Food was ok.

Ia2mg7J70FQ7M1nVILt5VQ.text: Red 8 is Wynn's informal Asian restaurant, open for lunch and dinner.  It serves a variety of Southeast Asian foods: Malaysian satays, Japanese noodles, Cantonese noodles and, on weekends, Hong Kong style dim sum.  Wynn Las Vegas has an array of excellent restaurants - all of them expensive.  Red 8 tries to fill a niche by providing good food at a modest price, relatively speaking.  Many dishes are in the $15 - $20 range, although there are a few luxury live seafood items that will set you back almost $100.  The breadth of the menu is surprising.  Among its offerings are Malaysian beef satays, Korean kim chee, Japanese udon noodles, Vietnamese pho, pad Thai, Indian mee goreng noodles, and Cantonese roast duck.  There's a single menu for lunch and dinner.  The restaurant is decorated in black, white and cream, with red accents.  Considering its location next to the casino, it's fairly quiet, with an informal feel.  There's a small communal table, but it doesn't seem very, well...communal.  I haven't noticed any conversations between strangers, and management doesn't help when it treats the table as overflow space when no other tables are available.  Service is a weak link at Red 8.  On my first visit, after I was finished eating, my server disappeared.  I waited for 15 minutes (actually a little bit longer than that, as I didn't check my watch right away), looking around for someone.  I finally managed to flag down a bus boy, and asked him to get my server.  She appeared a couple of minutes later, with no explanation.  On my second visit, service was better, but again there were some long waits.  On my third visit, I imitated a gentleman at a neighboring table who took a more direct approach: loudly hailing the server like a passing taxicab.  Crude, but effective.  ** DIM SUM Dim Sum is available for lunch on weekends.  There are no rolling carts; ordering is from a menu.  Each order comes as two or three pieces, so it would be more fun to order as a group, but ordering solo worked out OK.  It took a little while to prepare the food, but the wait wasn't too long.  I had: *   Shrimp in bean curd rolls.  Like a flat, fried egg roll, it was filled with shrimp, what tasted like shrimp paste, and bits of carrot and some green vegetable.  A dipping bowl contained Worcestershire sauce.  If you like bean curd skin, it's a very tasty dish. *   Deep fried taro dumplings.  Light and crispy outside, with soft (mashed?) taro inside, mixed with barbecue pork.  Very good+. *   Sticky rice in lotus leaf.  A rectangle of soft, sticky rice, with small shrimp and barbecued pork, wrapped in a lotus leaf. *   Thai ice tea.  Layered cream (?) on top of very sweet strong tea.  I liked it, but some people might have been turned off by the sweetness.  ** REGULAR MEAL #1 This time, I decided to try something different: *   Oriental green onion pancake.  Vaguely reminiscent of a quesadilla with scallions, but crispier.  Hoisin sauce was served as a condiment.  It didn't have much flavor; the hoisin sauce helped a little, but not much. *   Indian mee goreng with shrimp.  Wok-fried noodles, with onion and shrimp, and bits of a very hot pepper.  The portion was very large, probably best shared.  I thought the flavor was good, and the noodles were firm, but it was mostly just a big plate of noodles.  ** REGULAR MEAL #2 OK, maybe this doesn't exactly qualify as a regular meal.  However, I noticed a couple of interesting items on the menu, and was hooked.  What seemed so interesting?  Congee.  A thin rice porridge, it's felt to be a healthy dish, appropriate after one has been eating or drinking too well for a few days.  Kind of like thin oatmeal.  However, meat, chicken, fish, and other ingredients may be added to congee.  I chose to add pork and preserved egg.  The egg, sometimes called century egg or thousand year egg, is preserved in an alkaline solution.  Wikipedia has a good explanation.   The verdict?  Not bad.  As expected, it was pretty bland, but it actually had a little texture.  The pork gave it some flavor, and the preserved egg was interesting.  I don't know if I'd order it again, but I'm glad I tried it once.  I had planned to try an unusual dessert - sweet potato porridge with sago - but the huge bowl of congee had filled me up.  Maybe next time.  Red 8 isn't bad, but it also isn't that good.  Perhaps its menu is too ambitious ("Jack of all trades, master of none").  Perhaps I've been spoiled by all the excellent restaurants at Wynn.  In any case, I was hoping for better.  Nonetheless, it's convenient and not too expensive - and I don't know if there's any place better in this mid-range category.

AtLt9ADJMom5FEew3EezNg.text: Solid food with great service.  The waiter knew what vegan was and steered us towards the dishes he thought were the tastiest.  Overall, a nice lunch.

hiV9CtZh9Xkfd2shkr_1yg.text: We dined here because the buffet was a 3 hour wait. I am chinese and I was a little skeptical at first since this is a chinese restaurant in a western establishment. I was hungry and decided to give it a try. When I first saw the menu it had chinese characters so I thought to myself, 'ok maybe it won't be so bad'. For drinks I got the Thai Ice Tea (FYI, it was $5) which was too sweet. We ordered the crab yee mein and the braised beef stew. It was very delicious and most importantly authentic. The food tasted just like the ones you would find in San Gabriel, Alhambra, etc... However, being in Vegas the prices are different. For desert we had mango sago which paked a lot of mango flavor as well as mango pieces. Everything was really delicious.

iD87AnHcENMCZZ1srTDZcg.text: I've never really had a bad experience here at Red 8. I've probably eaten here about 10 times. I didn't have any service issues here. The servers pretty much only came out when they were needed, but they were easy to flag down to get what you needed. My only big gripe is that the dim sum selection is a bit smaller than you would expect at a Chinese restaurant. However, the two items that shine for me are the fresh guava juice (Yum! Definitely not Kern's nectar) and the egg custard buns. The pricing is a bit above average, but this is Vegas... and it's the Wynn. Show me a restaurant in a Vegas hotel/casino that isn't priced above your local Chinatown dim sum joint.

k_GunCsr7Hu7ucsvfxyRwA.text: We got to Vegas at 10 am and went straight to our hotel Encore to check in. we got hungry so we walked over to Wynn and found Red 8. me n my friend ordered 1 lunch plate together that had potsticker, eggroll, orange chicken n rice. then we ordered pork and shrimp dumpling...n we were still hungry! so we ordered a plate of bbq pork with rice on the side and of course we had mango pudding for dessert! after all that we were satisfied =) the service was great...refilled our water without us asking for it...they were attentive and overall a great restaurant! ohh n it was time for a nap after all that food....

qpggpAekzsvwNA4IaUoNyw.text: The service at this place is super slow to the point of nonexistence, the food comes out luke warm and don't expect a refill of hot water water for your tea, we waited 20 minutes and the server finally came back as we walking out the restaurant with the teapot.  The won ton soup is good but I wished they would have served it hot. The the crab noodles are pretty good but super greasy!

8bc8T6QQiZfXqdgOGh0FYA.text: Delicious, straight up fantastic! Therefore I am a greedy teenager and would love to have more of it in my plate. By the way that statement just shows how tasteful the food is. Would definitely recommend. Some plates may seem overpriced but trust me: what happens in Vegas stays in Vegas.

g7kV173q4Wfj4XoU89aSuQ.text: Red 8 was decent. All of the dim sum plates we had were great, but the entrees were just okay. The chive dumplings were so good! Seats weren't too comfortable, but otherwise a great atmosphere right on the edge of the casino.

5qwoyhS0xRdmDb7Ri_wnOQ.text: Loved this place! We always come to Vegas and stay at the Wynn and I usually eat at lakeside or Sinatra's.  I am sooo happy we found this gem! I would tell you what I tried but honestly don't remember the names. I can only imagine whatever you order will be amazing because I was really impressed. My wife also loved it and she is a tough customer.   Try it out, you won't be disappointed!

EeusIX7sI7ckrrbB9hFCmw.text: We were at the Wynn and decided to have lunch. After checking Yelp, Red 8 looked like it would be a good choice. We were immediately greeted and seated. It was a Saturday and was very busy for the lunch hour.   They have a nice dim sum menu along with several entrees. We started with the bbq pork buns and steamed shiu mai. Both came out quickly and were hot. The pork buns were okay, but I have had much better. The shiu mai were good, but didn't seem made fresh in house.   We also ordered the Shanghainese soup dumplings (3). We felt the same about these, they were good but we have definitely had better. We finished with chicken and broccoli which they made special for us and fried rice. The chicken and broccoli came out luke warm but the fried rice was excellent. For a $100 lunch I would expect much better food.   I saw many reviews complaining about the service but we had excellent service from Joanna and Dorothy throughout the meal. They were very friendly and constantly checked on us and made sure our drinks were full.   3.5 stars for the food 5 stars for service

ad3q0ohWin5S0gKTCFjhjw.text: A nice chinese restaurant with good food inside the Wynn.  Don't get lost walking over - it's kinda out of the way. Every thing was so tasty, especially the dumplings.  Seasonings were right on; super flavorful.  The stir fry came with Chinese broccoli and American? broccoli and BROWN RICE! yay. The atmosphere is great, the food is great; but at these prices, I'd expect better service.

DXqq6cLcfhh5r8h1_zVDxg.text: Great for vegetarian/vegans in Las Vegas!  Delicious Americanized Chinese food in the area.  Highly recommend the following: - Gardein "chicken" shu mai - Vegetables bun - Vegetables chow fun with Gardein "chicken" - Cashew Gardein "chicken" - Watermelon mocktail - Coconut tapioca dessert (off the menu)  Definitely ask for chili sauce on the side if you want more of that spicy kick in your food.  Btw, Red 8 is way better than Wazuzu. Just my two cents.

0N-90FWT9Nh7m6elVgdNJw.text: Even though we eat at Wynn/Encore weekly  (Vegas locals), this is our first visit to Red 8.    First of all, the food is fantastic.  Probably the best Sweet n Sour I've ever eaten .  Honey Glazed Prawns were massive and tasty!  Also had the combo fried rice and Cashew Chicken.  Definitely a do again.  We realized too late that we had not ordered anything spicy...will do that next time.    Service was way fast...almost too fast.  Literally like 3 minutes after ordering all the food arrived.  I was hungry but that's a bit quick.  Didnt get to fully enjoy the Ginger Green Bean appetizer.   Frankly the downer of the place are the seats.  They are child size patio chairs and neither my hubby or I were comfortable.  Our waiter quickly moved us to a bench seat but we saw other diners equally as uncomfortable.  We aren't skinny minis but we aren't huge either.  Kind-of average.  I imagine this is a problem for many people.  Took longer to get the check than the food.  :-(

twN50dLMLnMheWc76q5YxQ.text: The oxtail soup is out of the world, very reasonable pricing  Staff are very friendly and welling to go out of there way to make you happy  Dumpling are also amazing  I will be back before end of my visit

k96XsyqWsHu4SFOLDQM-dg.text: We have been here a few times in the last couple of years. Food is consistently great! If you like calamari switch it up and try the deep fried soft shelled crab (it's spicy but you should be able to get it mild if you ask).   Sometimes the line to get in is long but once seated the service is fast and friendly.

BIvuBT8YaZ7hK0rjo8jK_Q.text: Extremely overpriced, average-quality Chinese food. Service was also pretty bad...after being seated, we waited almost 30 min before our waiter came by, who proceeded to recommend the three most expensive things on the menu. He kept trying to up-sell us through the whole dinner which nearly ruined the experience. The one saving grace of this place is the great atmosphere and cool decor. I would hesitantly recommend this place if you don't mind average food and a pushy, inattentive wait staff.

ywKFHKrWbnGXXLxN7A13UA.text: High class Chinese food! :)  Its kind of funny cause back in Davis there is a Red88 not to get confused, 2 different things...  Surprisingly...with the high cost, the portions were not bad especially the fried rice dishes. Of course, your still looking at $10+ for some fried rice ($5 in normal places) but hey everything in Vegas is over priced.   Authentic or not? Actually Authentic, yet another surprise. it actually doesn't taste like it is completely catered to American Style.   Setting: Very nice and Asianish as in they have a lot of statues of budas and what not. Very Asian detailing on the walls and plates and the colors were RED (obvious from the name) and black.   Service: It was ok, not the greatest. Never really asked how we were doing and hard to get a hold of them.  Price: TOOOO Much for Asian food.   Duck: SoO goooood! it may look small but actually filling
