01ET4H5N-wuKlgMhBYZWSQ.text: Impressively authentic establishment for being a casino resto. Girlfriends and I were craving a break from the steakhouse regimen that is Vegas and came here courtesy rec from the concierge at Encore, where we were staying.  Must-order: Shanghai xiao long bao were well-made, delicate skin still preserving the dumpling broth inside, which was flavorful. Most US establishments (minus Ding Tai Fung and authentic dimsum houses in LA/SF/NY/Vancouver) can't make XLB to save their lives - skin too thick, not enough broth, etc.  Has a modest dimsum menu (made to order) - the shiu mai was yummy as was the luo buo gao (pan-fried turnip cake). Didn't care for the bbq pork in the cha siu bao (bbq pork buns) - the bread was decent, but the actual flavor was eh.  Noodles: Niu nan (beef tendon) noodle was decent, and for the less adventurous the pork & shrimp dumpling noodle was delish. Everything tasted fresh and well-made - zero MSG after-taste.  Decor is under-stated modern Chinese, red/white accents, black lacquer. Tastefully done. Restaurant is on the quieter side, which is good for a break. Prices are reasonable ($15ish for noodles, $9/dimsum dish).  Service was average but would return if I was staying at the Encore.

bOvDucFnys958A0Ba3v5Cw.text: This place is the inferior version of Wazuzu. Their service is TERRIBLE!  The waiter forgot to bring our Dim Sum order. When he finally returned to our table and I informed him of that, he told me that I hadn't ordered it. Yep! The waiter called me a liar and gave no semblance of concern. No "sorry about the mix up" or "I will get your order".  Seriously people?  This place is kind of expensive. You would expect much better.   Do yourself a favor. If you want high-quality Asian food, go to Wazuzu at the Encore. The experience will actually be worth the price.

CuIRYM7WFVSDt2t7Z_rEJg.text: Yummy Chinese!!  The service was decent and the food was great.  We shared a bunch of dishes and were adventurous.  They have good cocktails too.  It is Vegas priced.  We did not have reservations and were able to walk right in.  Great for groups, but they had tables for two as well.  Enjoy!!

XnRJ5rk1SWYs_RZprrW0Tw.text: I would've have given this place 4 or 5 stars because the food was delicious.  However, the food coming back up a few hours later was not so delicious.    My husband and I stayed at the Wynn since we had a 4 day weekend (Thanksgiving weekend).  On Saturday night, we decided to have some Chinese food.  I read the reviews and looked at the pictures on here and it looked great.  My husband was craving for Chinese food also.  We didn't have reservations and arrived around 6:30pm.  We were greeted and seated promptly.  The place wasn't crowded, but had a handful of groups already dining.    We ordered 4 items to share since a reviewer stated that they were small portions, which wasn't the case for us.  Didn't look like they were small portions.  I guess for me, the portions were just right.  We ordered the Roasted Duck, Beef with Noodles (it was very similar to Pad See Ew - Thai noodle dish), BBQ pork and Shrimp Fried Rice, and Soft Shell Crab.  Everything was great.  Food was good, very flavorful and so good.  Wait staff was great, friendly, and attentive.    Then a couple of hours later, while in our hotel room, my husband started vomiting.  He threw up about 10 times within 13 hours.  It was just awful.  I don't recommend eating the Soft Shell Crab.  I think that is what did it to us since that was the only one we shared.

eviPGVFD89MF4k5IcJN-xA.text: Lunch with my hot wife. The dim sum was delicious we had several kinds and everything was prepared perfectly. The service was excellent and the price was reasonable. I would definitely recommend this to anyone in the area where the special trip just to try the tasty delicacies.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. What a great day.

GwaoLzm3N-1dNgIqxGU8pA.text: Food is average, kind of westernized but service is great. It was really nothing special. I was looking forward to ordering the roast duck but I inquired and was told that it doesn't come with the wraps or filling like it should traditionally. Very disappointing for what is supposed to be a "proper" Chinese restaurant.

osElXPpahpHzelq-_65Adw.text: I'm going to say, of the Asian restaurants in Las Vegas in the hotels, I've had my share of good experiences, often followed by large dining bills.  Red 8 is right priced for the location.  The food quality and quantity is good.  I gotta say, I love their noodles.  Yes, you might find similar quality in Chinatown for a fraction of the cost, but you're in a casino where you might be dropping $20-50 per hand on blackjack or pulling slots, so in actuality, if you're going to throw money away like that in a gamble, a 'sure bet" is to treat yourself to a nice meal at Red 8, and you'll always walk away a winner!

b8YGxl0n67bP7ev1Yq-Jfg.text: Had lunch here today and it was great.   The service was formal but very friendly. I got to try:   Oxtail Soup Jade Dumplings  Shrimp Pad Thai  When she first set the oxtail soup in front of me, I was a little worried. Never having tried it, I did not know what to expect and the visible bone surprised me. Reservations aside, I tried the broth and it was excellent. From the broth on moved on to the carrot, carefully avoiding the bone. The vegetables were also delicious so I decided to go a hard and try the meat. It was excellent. Very tender and had a great flavor. I would absolutely order again.   The Jade Dumplings also looked a little bizarre as they are bright green. They were also delicious. Very moist and tasty filling.   The shrimp on the Shrimp Pad Thai were huge and full of flavor. The rest of the dish was pretty standard fare. I had asked for my Pad Thai to be extra spicy but I felt like it lacked heat. All in all, I love Pad Thai and this dish satisfied.   I will definitely be back to try another dish.

lFdGQVTB01qAq6Q3WxAIcg.text: 2 Pork Shao Lung Boa - 16.00 1 Shiu Mai - 9.00 1 Snow Pea Leaf - 28.00  ==  Yes Twenty Eight 1 Iced Tea - 4.50  Total Lunch (Not Including Tax) $62.16  MSG bomb all over.  Most chinese ppl would find this restaurant offensive.  I only ate here b/c I saw Mr Wynn himself eating lunch here.  I wouldn't come back.  They also have a terrible service issue.   More specifically, the servers standing there.  Not servicing the customers.  No need to bring your own soy sauce...food's salty enough.

cixmKU-m-2RudQPGB6CauA.text: So for the people who know me, they know I primarily stay at the Encore or Wynn resorts only. A group of us we're at the pool for the majority of the day and then got hungry so we decided to go to Red 8 at the Wynn side. We approached the hostess desk to get a table for 4 and she told us that she can't help us because they have a dress code and can't seat one of our persons since he's wearing a tank top. Mind you he's not wearing a wife beater and there were a few people seating who had on tank tops. Also to add, we were staying in the Tower suites at the Encore so not like we're rift raft just strolling thru the property. We pointed out to the hostess that they have people seated and eating who are wearing tank tops and all she kept saying was that's their "resort dress code policy". I find that amusing since we ate at Jardin a few hours before dressed in the same attire. My group then asked to speak to a manager and someone else came out just reiterating the same thing. I then asked for the general managers name and card so I can contact them. The manager what for and I told her, ( named Ida Shek) to inform them how we're being treated. Both my host and attorney will both be hearing of this. I'm all for rules, laws, and equality.... but don't tell me it's not allowed when there's other people inside dressed the same way. Did they treat us like that because we're of darker skin tone? Because my friend with the tank top is gay?

loY_tujrnrP0Qm0cM4fTZQ.text: This was the best Chinese food i've ever had!!!!  I would give them 10 stars if I could!!!  The Fried rice was light and very tasty!!  The Oxtail soup was unbelievably delicious!!!

NVlSA4ajErB2acGxpz19bw.text: The restaurant near XS was closed so my wife and I decided to come here. We really enjoyed the vegan options they had. The price was about a hundred dollars for the both of us. We only had the dim sum and one order of lettuce wrap. The Gardein Shumai was pretty good for not being the real thing, but the dumplings stuck together. The Gardein Buns were really good. Overall we really enjoyed ourselves. Great atmosphere and friendly service, even though it was pretty slow. The food was pretty good too. I believe I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much if I wasn't a vegan.

H_rGucul8MbcEmyUslpfyA.text: Really low end considering it is in the Wynn Hotel.  No reservations so "make sure you stay right here".  We only waited 10 minutes.  The service was not too slow but not too friendly either. My husband liked his Mongolian beef.  I thought the veggie fried rice was a bit on the oilier side.  We were pretty Vegased out by this meal and wouldn't have enjoyed much of anything but smoke free air.

348OaZXijXIHj7WQsvlIpw.text: They were out of Chilean Sea Bass, so we had to order the steamed Rock Fish.  This entre alone was $120.00.  It only barely fed one person.  All skull and bones.  Do not order this, it is a total major rip off.  Felt for my brother since he recommended this restaurant and I was afraid to askhim  what the total bill was.  I'm guessing $300 for three people. The rest of the meal was minimal and left us hungry.  Had to go to place in the food court nearby later for a snack.

eUtMtFYazw0vvAgRMKJ_sA.text: I was most definitely underwhelmed by this place. My aunt hyped it up a bit. She kept talking about the preserved egg congee, so it got us a little excited.  Damn, damn. Just looking at the menu made me not want to eat. Padt thai for 23 bucks? No thanks. I didn't want the congee because it wouldn't make me full, so I got the udon with fish balls and fish cakes. That was only 12 bucks but soo underwhelming. There was no flavor at all so I had to add a whole bunch of chili oil. My aunts liked it but my dish was definitely not good. I tried some of my cousins padt thai. I could have gotten the same in San Jose for half the price. Not coming back.. well maybe I'll try the congee one day.

CHWC4zhGXGPy1kMKOiTfAg.text: It's amazing how after two years, Red 8 hasn't changed anything about how they train their staff!  The service was bad the first time we came here - we actually walked out after ten minutes since no one came to ask us for a simple drink order or even acknowledge our existence.  There was a long line outside but lots of empty tables inside; they just couldn't get their act together about bussing the tables!  This time, we got seated immediately and quickly got drink service.  Only four other tables were occupied, a couple of tables already had their dim sum order, so we figured it was good to get there at opening.  WRONG!  Even with more than 3 waiters and a few more men walking around in black tees - no idea what they were since they enjoyed chatting and laughing amongst themselves but not really seat or serve anyone.  At one point, the host was pouring water for guests!  Beats the hell out of me what the other five men and one woman staff were doing!  Our waiter, an Asian guy was good and did the best he could even though it looked like he was out of breath trying to get to every table on our side of the restaurant.  It's not a big restaurant.  They were just inefficient in service.  They sat a party of five at a square table for four and a party of three at a booth where no one actually say on the booth but just on three chairs around the booth.  Go figure!  Dim sum is the easiest way to get your food FAST.  That includes congee!  However, it was a slight wait and some of the food wasn't even warm!  It baffled and annoyed me.  What's worst then eating bad food is food that is not warm!!  The food is tasty but I expected more.  No I didn't expect to have the best dim sum I have ever had but I did expect a higher standard here.  After all, the Wynn is supposed to take care of the serious high rollers and we know just how many Asians are so.    The soy bean milk here is not sweetened which sucks.  We (Asians) all drinks sweetened soy milk and if not sweetened, given syrup on the side to add.  Sugar does not melt and no one adds bloody syrup to soy milk!!  BTW, don't order the hainanese chicken rice!  I had the chicken rice (room service) and the rice isn't flavorful enough, the soup tastes weird, chicken is dry and the chilli they use is out of a bottle you can buy from the store (sambal olek).  What a disappointment.  I won't return or test my luck again.

wz2XRMv3NRxYPAzR7v2myQ.text: Stopped in here for dinner as it was located closest to my hotel room. Compared to other restaurants in the Wynn-Encore compound this one lacks. The food is hit or miss; the service was slow and lackluster (they were not that busy) and the cost is high. There are better options in Vegas and even within the Wynn-Encore indoor mall.

V4QlQM_FPizWskM6ovHpUw.text: oooooohhh why Wynn, why?  The presentation is beautiful. Vibrant red and gold! Silk and Satin! Comfy booths! Why does your food taste so bad?  Let me break it down:  Beef Satay- lukewarm, beef was very chewy and grisly, good peanut sauce but nothing special, needed more spice. Singapore Rice- taste like curry powder tossed with rice. woopie. Phad Thai Noodles- smelt like Alpo. Taste was mild, shrimp were bland Kung Pao Chicken- ok, really saucy and very few peanuts, chili oil was separating  THE ONLY really good thing I ate there were their fried turnip cakes with taro. these hold a wow factor that nothing else on the menu can bring! We ordered two more after we tried the entrees.   The food was so disappointing that we gave all our left overs to a homeless man who was sitting near the Hooters Casino. Is that mean?

3_0MbRKldJr9CM_U3D-iew.text: It is probably a 3.5 star place, but here is my review.  The location is nice, not too pretentious, but you can be, if it makes you happy. It seemed to make some of the people there very happy to feel pretentious.  The food was very solid, the broth on my won ton noodle soup was nice and light, and the won ton were flavorful and made of good ingredients. My Fiancee's potstickers had very good filling, and dipping sauce, though the skin thickness left for a little debate.  The satay was well cooked, and the sauce was decent, though a little lacking on flavor.    The service was a slow, and a bit rude. Now, the question is,... is that what you should expect from an Asian noodle place, or were we applying Western standards to the place that shouldn't have been applied? We'll have to see if we ever return and pay the high prices for decent food.  It's cheap for the Wynn, but not for the rest of the world, and the food is solid...just mediocre service.

lYeHXBcyC4L6HKFoJefG7g.text: Decided to try this place out after watching La Reve. Quick summary -   - long wait to be seated - longer wait to place our order - overpriced for average food.

Yr_kTZPfSDDTzC6GDLDnuA.text: I stayed at the Wynn Tower Suites, and was tired from exhibiting the show all day. So i decided to take the first restaurant near the tower suites. Ordered the following. Since i know it's probably not as authentic as i would like it to be so the basics should be easy enough for the chef to handle and me and my dad would have no problem enjoying the following  1) Chicken Friend Rice  2) Beef Chow Mien (oily)  3) Garlic String Beans (oily)   All around it was enjoyable spending $70 including tips on the above following with a coke and green tea, we thought that was the end of a basic and pricey PANDA express. Well I was wrong. It is 2:37am and i am still awake and dieing of thirst, my dad has a minor headache. I guess the MSG they put in the food was way too powerful. After 2 bottles of water and an orange juice i am still awake with the bad taste of MSG in my mouth. If your OK and not allergic to MSG this is place to go. I would think for the price they pay they can do better without artificial taste of MSG.

dNQNCXL_iNYjFe5E8pY8AQ.text: I'm really surprised at the low rating Red 8 has gotten here.  I think this is an excellent place for Chinese.  I make sure to go each trip.    I don't find it to be that expensive considering it's really good and in the Wynn.  I would like to see a bigger Dim Sum selection.  But the BBQ pork is top notch.    I did knock a star off for slow service.  I once walked out (without paying) after waiting 15 minutes for my check.

WrB-8YtRMgjJjPZBRQLnjw.text: I wish I had read some of these reviews prior to taking Rachel Ray's word for it. The food was ok nothing to write home about. I would choose differently next time.  Think twice before going.

e8UR5dwCOobPP_qgtco1pw.text: Chinese food is supposed to be somewhat economical.  I know that this is the Wynn and I am supposed to be getting mad comps to offset the overpriced food, but this is a little ridiculous.  $9 for hot and sour soup?  Granted it was made well and such, but dang, it was a portion for one!  $26 for 8 oz of duck and 6 oz of BBQ pork?  $18 for beef chow mein?  It was enough for two... maybe.  $9 for plain congee for one?  Here's the ugly truth.  I was comped $80 for 10 hours of blackjack (which is a mildly crappy food comp, by the way).  Somebody's got to pay for that.  It's the same reason why the Buffet is $33 for Sunday brunch (no champagne).  None of this explains why the Wynn Buffet is so terrible though, but I'm getting off topic here.  Anyway, if you are a big fish (or maybe a mini-whale), I'm sure you won't care, but for us mortals, it sort of matters that this really is a pretty bad deal.  And Wynn's comps sort of suck... grrr... sorry, off topic again.

FS7sPgVV_dqddIMsZm6IMg.text: Good food, but terribly expensive for what it is. This is over-priced chinese food served in a fantastic dining room. I love the decor, and I do love the fact that it's right in the casino. I think the management over stretches the waitstaff and the service is so-so. I hate it when I see my waiter in the weeds and the manager just hangin' back and watching the room. Like... HEY MANAGER MAN LOOKING IMPORTANT- How about you help out your staff who has like a 10 table section? Or... just got 2 -12 tops sat at the same time?!  It's the customer who ultimately suffers so work with the team "manager man" and crack open a beer for the table who's parched and desperately looking around for someone to quench their thirst!

266YmsLqFnV4MMylGZF2vA.text: Loved the vegan options! Both my husband and I were impressed with the food and service. Fresh, vibrant and tasty meals. House made lemon soda was outstanding!

dw5I0HgxS-N5BdYo1vzMUg.text: I ordered the special dumpling noddle soup and to be honest, it wasn't all that special. It was pretty bland in my taste and overpriced! But then again...it IS vegas so you can't expect much. Overall experience is average.

sn7HYL3mw37JG9h8Xbj00Q.text: Ok, granted we were here when Wynn first opened, this place sucked! the service was extremely terrible. the food was mediocre! Gosh....we were not happy at all! This place probably got better but, first impression, "hell no!"

m9vn5185pumzGlZfsRGrMg.text: I'm a little surprised to see that Red 8 only gets 3 stars I ate their last night and really enjoyed it. The quality of food and service was just fine. I had the Mongolian chicken and Andy had Sweet and Sour Chicken both were large portions and very good. we shared Dim Sum Pork and Shrimp that was really well made. it was a little expensive but what isn't in Vegas.

iVjJ54FbkqcGGuYnvW8Sjw.text: decent but not extraordinary Hong Kong noodle house cuisine, but WAY overpriced ($7 for a pot of hot tea? An outrage!) Staff was attentive and professional.

ShUaVIeyU_Y0yBjyLqTrog.text: They get a three for being able to seat a party of 12 right away without reservations. That was great to not have to wait! The food, while not stellar by a Chinese person's standard, passes as decent junkie Chinese food.  Our table ordered several dim sum dishes, fried rice, fried noodles, sweet and sour pork, mongolian beef, and others that I can't recall. Everything was really salty, and when I tried to take sips of my mango juice to wash the saltiness away, my mango juice tasted like medicine and left a bitter aftertaste in my mouth. I have to say though, the flavors were on par with what you'd expect (sweet and sour tasted like it would at another restaurant, the dim sum tastes like it would elsewhere, etc).   Our waiter was very accommodating, especially since our party kept growing as people came wandering in late. He was very good about making sure we had our drinks, that the newcomers were included and got food, etc.  Overall, good solid service, food is average, but definitely something I'd eat again if in the right company/mood.

t4MR_MEEhIVxsiWqPOQXhg.text: It's a bit pricey yes but you're in Vegas and you're at the Wynn.  Why am I giving this place four stars and not the three like everyone else?  First of all, nice decor.  The decor is nicer than Noodles and Zine which are two comparative Chinese restaurants on the strip.  Second, the noodles, fried rice and the mango sago with pomelo was better than any restaurant that I've ate at here in the Bay Area.  I'm talking about SF where Chinese food should be good but it isn't as good as Red 8.  I like this place as a quick stop for noodles and fried rice like an afternoon snack or late night snack.

8zgW6RbDj2Asl-33deFZvA.text: At first look, I thought it was a contemporary Chinese fusion type of cuisine. Surprisingly it was very traditional Chinese. It ox tail soup was amazing. The portions are up to the price. The flavor was very good.

fhaonB3wzU159dZWhDmfzg.text: Red 8 is a semi-casual asian restaurant thats located in the Wynn casino. The ambiance is pretty good and keeps with the theme of elegance that surrounds the Wynn. I was a little surprised though that they provided cheap bamboo chopsticks instead of the nicer looking ones I usually find in more upscale asian restaurants.  The menu has favorites from different asian cuisines. From  the dim sum offerings we tried the shrimp dumplings and veggie rolls. Both were tasty and well cooked.  For the entrees we got the seafood Laska, the penang flat noodles and the broccoli dish for my vegetarian friend. All of us liked our entrees for the most part. I think the dishes could be more spicy but I have that complaint with most places. They did provide some hot sauce to spice it up.  One of my friends had the Mojito which he said was pretty good. I had the Tsing Tao which was just what I needed.   Its obviously a little expensive overall but thats to be expected in a place like the Wynn.

p2zgXQLKUK4zeCO7L5dvOw.text: My $9 could've bought me a pack of Skittles in my room... and instead it bought me three delicious BBQ pork buns.  Based on that and that alone, I can say that Red 8 is the best money for your dollar at the Wynn.  Cheers!

gdPmd3n6ey2a1-I4BleRTw.text: ARE YOU SERIOUS? a 3 star on yelp? you've got to be kidding me. as an indonesian chinese(who speaks mandarin) who grew up in singapore and had travelled to hong kong for the millionth time and been to most part of china, this restaurant offered just the best chinese food i'd had in america! (had to be more precise so my 5* rating would be valued) yes some of them aren't authentic but screw it, because its shiu mai was fucking good. the last time i stayed at Wynn(which was last may/june), i was here about 2-3 times. this time, i was here for another 3 times, not including the dimsums we had for room service. we had our regular dimsum and i liked everything but cha siew bao(pork bun) because 1.i'd tasted better ones 2.it didn't taste like pork at all. i think there was something else mixed in there(human meat?) but it didn't taste good. one of my favorite dim sum, sesame rice ball, wasn't that good either. disappointed. however, the har gow, siew mai, kway teow, century egg+pork floss congee(room service), can't remember a hundred other dim sum we had, but they were just 5*. i'd never even had that good a kway teow in singapore. THE CHILLY!! the chilly casted a spell on us. how can there be such a good chilly made? spicy and sweet at the same time. even better than the one i made. comparable to indonesian chilly. it was so good my korean friend and i each requested for some to be taken home. it's not over! i haven't mentioned the service yet! one of the korean lady server(i asked if she was japanese because she was so hospitable). everyone else was good but she was excellent.

3FVyU4_wkPf6cjGf8OW_mA.text: My husband and I had just gotten into Vegas for a long weekend and we were starrrrrving.  I didn't want the typical room service type fare, so we went looking for something different.  We were staying at the Encore so we just walked through our hotel over to Wynn and stumbled upon Red 8.  We walked up to the restaurant and saw the words dim sum and that did it for us.  We were sold.  We each got cocktails which were tasty but forgettable.  Nothing special here.  We ordered dim sum and appetizers only since we had dinner in a few hours and didn't want to fill up.  We ordered - Steamed pork buns - Amazing.  Sooooo light and fluffy Shrimp dumplings - Very good, but nothing fancy Chicken Satay - The chicken was good but the peanut sauce was a little boring Pot stickers - Fantastic.  Extra meaty.  Sometimes pot stickers are all filler and no meat, not the case here.  We left very satisfied but craving more pork buns.  They were soooooo good.

miyhoA4eChpmNMTSRBln-A.text: I'm surprised about the low rating Yelpers have given this place. I've been here several time and the service is fast and friendly and the food was great. They have some interesting, unusal things on the menu I was unfamiliar with, but our waiter made some great suggestions and we enjoyed our meal. It is a little more expensive then most Chinese restaurants, but very reasonable for Las Vegas. I also love the decor of this place, its small but beautiful.

KTkuq-mwddp7WMxxual-ww.text: Don't listen to the people who rave about this place.  Take it from me, if you have never eaten Chinese food before or you think Panda Express is just lovely, than you'll think this is Chinese food heaven.    But if you've ever had any decent Chinese food in your life, you'll be disappointed.  The food is bleh compared to most mid-level Chinese restaurants you can find on any corner of any street in the U.S.  For Chinese food, the prices are extremely expensive, but I wouldn't mind paying for it if the quality was there.  Ambiance is great.  Tastefully decorated- even down to the dishware.  I like going in there just for drinks.  They really need to hire more staff.  I've been here a few times and each time the waiters are running around with their heads cut off.    Overall, I expect better at The Wynn.

F60QZZAVDhRDole6ciUJbg.text: Was not impressed. Appetizers, entrees, service, the whole bit. I expected a lot more. I basically ended up eating rice for $100. I told my waiter I didn't like the appetizers, and sent them back practically untouched, I was still billed for them. I do not waste my time giving bad reviews but I was so underwhelmed by this place. The quality of the food was poor, but if you like overpriced Mcnugget satay go for it .

BKbggaVVlsCQf20emfgkCA.text: Probably one of the worst "Asian" food experiences I've had in my entire life.   For being at such a classy and glamorous location as The Wynn, I expected so much more. The only saving grace of this place is their unique selection of cocktails. Everything that we ordered was overcooked, drenched in oil, and lacked flavor. I do not recommend this place to anyone wanting to have a quality LV experience. Save you $$ and get sushi/Asian at the MGM.

2zYVbEr5seK4Q7pZCk8e3Q.text: It's tough to pay this kind of money for Chinese comfort food, but the dishes I ordered were surprisingly very good. Beef stew soup noodles: $16 Black bean sauce spare ribs: $6 Vegetarian egg rolls: $7 Pot of pu-erh tea: $7

op23fsA7CZxcewcncYWNHA.text: This place serves standard chinese food in a slightly more upscale setting.  It's an easy spot to grab a bite to eat while at the Wynn.  Great service and  you will get out of there for about $30 a person.  If you are a people watcher get a table by the window and make fun of all the people you see strolling thru the casino.

l21Hn1-xTJgOYCbvvQM4jA.text: This is a good choice if you're looking for a relatively casual and inexpensive meal in Vegas. My wife and I went here on a weeknight for dinner and there was no wait at all. We didn't want a full meal as we had had a big lunch, so we opted for just drinks and entrees. She had the Sweet & Sour Chicken and I had the Kung Pao Chicken - both staples on the American Chinese menu. The portions were adequate, but we may have wanted a little more if we had been hungrier. Nevertheless, it was still a very good meal.  The atmosphere is quite eye-catching as you walk by the restaurant with its red decor (hence the name). We were seated by a window looking out to the Wynn casino floor, but didn't find it overly loud or distracting.  After our meal, tax, and tip the total came to about $55 for the two of us (two entrees and non-alcoholic drinks).

aa7VO5TpkV4o1fHJE5KJqg.text: I was very much looking forward to dining at Red 8. And yes, the food was okay. And yes, the restaurant decor is slick and cool, giving it a very hip atmosphere.  But I'm sorry, the menu is not that imaginitive or extensive, and frankly I've had food of this par from Chinese takeout. Also, the service was only so-so.   In other words, it's WAY over priced for what you get. Seriously, don't bother.

rhUbgucjrcwMfYJ-OnzgJg.text: slowest service ever.... had to ask a couple of times just to get water. And then, I asked for something on the healthier side. Response from waiter: the chow mein. ummmm, let's try that again.  Is there something that isn't too oily? His response: poached chicken with ginger oil.  At this point, I was ready to laugh. I was so tired and hungry though I just told him to bring that out with the side of veggies. and.... there are not that many meals I just won't eat. I mean, I really really like good food, but I'm not too picky of an eater. This chicken I would not eat. I ate a little because I was starving and decided I would rather be hungry than finish it. It was 90% fat, it looked disgusting, and it didn't taste much better. The veggies were safe, steamed, simple with absolutely no flavor.  I wish, wish, wish, I had walked into any other restaurant.

QbDQhTki0-Wsd5xna3q01g.text: Stopped into this restaurant impromptu...  Service was good, a bit slow to get food to table but food was superb.

Y6Cq-f_7wtS7FKcZu7lMIQ.text: Popped in for a very late dinner here while staying at the Encore. The food was great-prawn din sum were perfectly prepared and flavorful, veggie curry was flavorful with yummy tofu and veggies and  my wife's panang noodles were outstanding. Prices were reasonable and portions were not skimpy.   The place loses two stars, however, for service. Our waiter never came back to check on drink refills until we were long done and it took ages to get the check. There was hardly anyone there at the late hour so there really was no excuse. It's too bad because it would have been five stars otherwise.

K8-3H-q4qYQLezNBZ1H8ig.text: Something you don't see too often... a high end Chinese restaurant that is still moderately priced. They label it a casual Asian bistro and that's exactly what it is, albeit the fact that it's right in the heart of the Wynn Hotel, which is anything but.  Being so close to the casino floor, the type of energy and noise spills into the restaurant, which works in this case. The food also is nothing too foreign that you need a server to help you understand  it, but fast food takeout superstars like fried rice, mapu tofu and chicken satay are all on the menu here and done with an obvious higher attention to detail. Only bad thing was the service was noticeabley a bit scattered.

ibbIdjDxJ2kHv-oFfQb1IQ.text: I had lunch here today and it was nothing special. I had their dim sum and I think the the taste was just mediocre.  The quality of the food was alright as it didn't taste bad, but was not super tasty as well.   I only waited for about for about 5 minutes for my table. The food came about relatively quick, but I didn't see the waiter come by again until I finished my meal.

YrLkIbjgxp70p35m_CS-ew.text: Very tasty and fast service!  A cheaper option for a nice meal out.  Spent $70 on two entrees and two drinks.  Not a bad deal for the quality of the food.  Very creative and unique menu.  Lots of vegetarian options!

MNaQvLlWtVhC5n5-RiRvgg.text: Great food  Good vegan and vegaterian options  Pricey   Great service   Spring rolls were amazing.   Amazing martinis

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delish flirtini

8CgWfjzQxyVakZmlKWKsmg.text: This is our go to place for Chinese comfort food while on the Wynn premise.  We have been coming to this place for years and the consistency is amazing in terms of food quality and service. Our favorites are their fried noodles and dim sums.  We have tried most of the dishes and they are all yummy good.  Unless you go off strip, this place does not disappoint.

PBiWjgYLhjGIFyFHsatpBA.text: First impression, this place is beautifully decorated with a lot of red and gold accented furniture. The Asian in me highly approve the decor!   As for the food, I feel like the entrees are either a hit or miss depending on what you order. I was with a party of 5 and from looking at other dishes I wish I had ordered something different. But instead, my 'Classic dan dan noodles with pork' dish paled in comparison to the Beef Chow Mein or the Mongolian Beef that my friends ordered. My biggest complain about the classic dan dan noodles with pork is that there was no pork and that I had to mix my own sauces and seasoning. The black sauce that came with this dish was super salty so you have to be conservative while mixing it or else you'll end up with a dish that is bland yet overly salty.   I also asked for the palm pocket, an expensive dim sum item that was nothing to rave about. Now I understand the mix of bad and good ratings for this place. Be careful what you order!

0xAuZcoNdouZ7t1P9GyUGg.text: Amazing place.  Stylish.  Clean. Fresh.  Food is amazing and the portions are huge.  Tables are not crammed together.  Wish there were a few more pork dishes

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kung Pao Chicken

Fad3Aiwk4DgIgRxJq-Y7Og.text: I DID NOT EAT HERE. Even though they don't advertise it on the menu, Red 8 serves SHARK FIN. Please do not support businesses that practice this disgusting tradition.

ldUosiGbY9_mWzc1Av3LVw.text: Got into Vegas and didn't want to leave the hotel for dinner. Didn't want to spend $200 on dinner at the higher end places so we opted for Red 8. The decor and atmosphere is nice. We ordered a mixed drink and it was nice. Started with the Hot and Sour soup (good but not outstanding) and the Traditional Beijing Noodles with sauce (good). I asked the waiter why the noodles didn't have any pork and he told me it is ground up in the sauce. It would probably good to have that described on the menu. I opted for the $23 roast duck. The duck and sauce were tasty but that was it...you got a few pieces of duck and sauce...no veggies, no rice no nothing...$23. My husband ordered the lamb special $28. Cooked nicely and he enjoyed the sauce. At least with his dinner he received rice. Overall the food was good but still overpriced for what you received. Total for dinner was $100 not including tip.

m7enzs846tIFh4xhdOsa9w.text: Expensive dim sum items for the amount of food you get.  The dumplings are excellent though!!

Q1PfH3-Pi5iQcjCGEEy-NA.text: Went for dinner with coworkers. We were very impressed with the attentive service. The appetizers came out quickly and they were all enjoyed. The meals were equally appreciated.  Big portions. I definitely enjoyed the vegan options - REAL vegan options. I had the Gardein Chick'n Shiu Mai as the entree and it was delicious.

TBXamH7KFT5tuwY0D9Ed8Q.text: I guess I'm not getting all of the wonderful reviews. I thought Red 8 was really just "okay". I ate here on a Wednesday night after flying in, and it was a little bit late as well, so the place was pretty empty. It's very low energy, which might be good if that's what you're searching for.  Our waiter was nice enough but not at all helpful - no suggestions, no explanation of the menu regarding sizes of the dishes or recommendations regarding whether we should share, etc. I live in South Central Texas, so although I love Asian food, I'm no expert at ordering it because other than disgusting, huge Chinese buffets, there are no Asian restaurants around here. I needed help knowing how big the dishes were to order properly, so I felt lost. I would have loved to have been more adventurous in my ordering and tried new things, but the menu is just lists of dishes and zero explanation about what's in them.  We ended up with pork steamed buns, spring rolls, a bowl of Hot and Sour soup, and Kung Pao Chicken. The steamed buns - one of my favorite things - were disappointing. They weren't cooked properly, so they were gooey, not soft and delicious, and I found the round, ball-like presentation not what I was expecting since I've only ever had them shaped more like a taco. The spring rolls were fine (it's a spring roll). My mother had the Hot and Sour soup, and she's so extremely unable to tolerate spice that her eyes were watering, she was sniffling, and she couldn't finish a third of it. I had the Kung Pao Chicken, and conversely, I found it bland but decent.  I really don't see any reason I'd go back to Red 8, and I certainly wouldn't recommend it.

zuyD6w0BlbvRNQXeuUaCKQ.text: Ok.  This place isn't exactly open to 12.  Just went by and they actually stop serving at 11.30.  Not sure why they don't just say that.  Travelled quite a ways to be here so a bit disappointed.

gEk9xtIqsMziawnuJdOF2Q.text: Red 8 is good in a pinch.  Especially at lunch time when Wing Llei does not want to open for you.    In particular the ox tail soup is surprisingly good.  The string beans are perfectly cooked albeit a little over seasoned.  The chow fun is mediocre but not bad.  The dim sum items are hits and misses with some strangely peculiar flavors.    All in all, if you're extremely lazy and don't want to leave the Wynn/Encore buildling like me, this place ain't too shabby.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States

fyLpPUxYmTeftPATuCsluQ.text: I would give this restaurant a solid 3 stars. I was disappointed with the dining experience because it is located in the Wynn so I expected better. Unfortunately we did not check the Yelp rating before going or we would have passed because it is expensive for the rating.

zq35mvx9Fz6M9FLPIP2fJw.text: The dining experience was bad.  The service was terrible. They did not follow any of our requests and had to send back the food!

t-yCuwGXsi_q5UBAOd89MA.text: Went to dinner with work friend ... Service was mediocre and the serving size for tenderloin pepper steak that cost $38 USD was super small with more onion than meat. Upon bringing this fact to the attention of our server, he said it was high quality meat hence the small quantity of meat .. The meat was tough and not tasty .. My advice is save your money and avoid this restaurant if you don't want to be ripped off and get bad service.

oh4hh4Iu6TW6MuTZmR5erQ.text: Stopped in for some quick dim sum.  The dumplings were very good! Would love to try dinner!

k7KlbETuPbnn7fPHB69Dig.text: Love Red8, the food, service and atmosphere were exceptional and best of all they offer gluten free dishes. We look forward to our next stay at beautiful Wynn of which will most certainly include dinner at Red8

SlKhmRHwSwWmSFbdxWR4zg.text: Some. Ice vegan dishes. Vegan siu Mai dumplings were good. Jade dumplings too. Unfortunately no vegan noodle soups. Service iffy.   The vegan chicken lettuce wraps were fantastic.   Unfortunately like all the restaurants near the casino area, the smoke wafts into the whole room. Almost ruins it.

uQyOnXAg0kVldlTa4Yae8w.text: Fake Chinese food! Don't order any noodle, dim sun and deserts. The ice water is the only thing we like.

23jXC4GNNkggtxA5tHoDJA.text: Tipical americanized chinese food:greasy and too sweet. Althought shanghainese also has sweet and heavy sauces,it doesnt taste that rich. Orange beeftastes relatively better but its fried and very sweet which means its unhealthy and high-calorie.Gardein chick'n lettuce wrapsmy favourite that night,not too heavy and its vegetarian,just a little too salty but its okey wiz rice.Wok fired chinese lettuce,preserved tofusuch a disappointment!Not authentic!its not shanghainese!way too greasy!Braised tofu,ground chicken and salty fish in clay potsmells fishy...disgusting. Try another restaurant guys,this is not authentic chinese food. By the way,its way too pricy for the taste.

HPIgy1oe4D8ncGj899OlDw.text: Bad service, nasty Chinese food. Servers walk like turtles. Do not eat here.  U will rather take taxi to china town for better food.

S09n3g7-ljA5zDRVQWPC9Q.text: The foods were so fresh and delicious. My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our lunch. I ordered shiu mai and a bowl of fish balls & fish cakes vermicelli. The noodle bowl was a little blend but it was exactly what I wanted that afternoon. My husband had sweet and sour pork, and rice. He was impressed with his dish.   Service was a little slow, and foods are definitely overpriced but we would dine here again.

xcWPK_pxzm2cWgSuvQ1YOA.text: This beautiful Asian restaurant inside the Wynn Las Vegas is one to try! It is a bit pricey for the portions, but equally the quality and environment make up the difference.   We tried pork fried rice and a delightful noodle dish, but were a tad bit disappointed in the overall service. This is likely a result of going late in the evening and plan to visit again earlier to truly experience the restaurant when busy.  In closing, do try and hope you enjoy it as much as we did.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States

o521ZEN-yAmKKh17-HZq_w.text: I am a huge fan of Red 8!  Located inside the Wynn hotel, it is a really beautiful place with upscale ambiance. The prices are on the higher end for most chinese restaurants, but the atmosphere, service, and quality of the food fit the price.  My favorite dish here is the mongolian beef and the fried rice.  The hot & sour soup is also a great choice for an appetizer to share.  They offer many seafood options and many authentic dishes as well. The eggrolls here are not my favorite, but I am picky when it comes to Chinese food.  Highly recommend this spot if you are in the mood for an elevated Chinese food experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chilean Sea Bass - Gluten Free
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp Pad Thai

dYYuI_f4v_W8Dab7SQISZA.text: We were looking for a late night mid-week dinner and we found this place quite by accident while wandering around the Wynn Encore Casino. We put our name in for a table and was told it would be 30 minutes. 20 minutes later, we got a text message saying our table was ready!   It is lovely inside and the menu was extensive with your typical Americanized Chinese food but srpinkled with more traditional dim sum fare. We ordered the crab rangoon (very good); Oxtail soup (excellent), Miso soup (good); steamed pork buns (not good); Penang Style Flat Rice Noodles with Shrimp (excellent); a duck special (very good); Red 8 Combination Fried Rice (very good).   All in all, it was a good meal.  The server was quite good and my son recognized quickly that each meal price ended with $.88. That was a nice touch. There are so many options of places to eat at the Wynn and on the Strip. This is not a bad option for a casual meal. Prices are what you'd expect from a casino restaurant.

8XRWBNiJm4xrRlaVq9HcBg.text: Best Mongolian beef I ever had. And this is a dish I will probably order all the time if it is on the menu. The restaurant is beautiful. (There is no Bar here. Only tables). Service is very professional. And prices are fair (after all it is the Wynn so everything is usually more expensive than the average). Also had noodles that were ok. And pineapple mojito that was perfect. Overall it is a restaurant I will return to. Even if just for a mojito and their amazing Mongolian beef. Give them a try next time you are in the area.

RXjk_jWqrghcRRbh2_c0Ug.text: Had a bad experience here the last time. Quality was good but the service was really bad and management did nothing about it. Thanks Wynn

VkRzGN6gRj-J5I69xMB-_w.text: Nothing short of Amazing!! I ate here with 3 friends and we ordered 4-5 dishes to share. The Beef and broccoli was delish with just the right seasoning and the beef was tender as can be. The Chinese vegetables were savory and even the rice with egg was appreciated by all. Laslty, the dish of the night is the duck! It was succulent with crispy skin and tender meat underneath. The thing that I appreciated the most that each dish tasted different and had very different flavors. No MSG here. The service was professional and discreet. The only feedback I would offer the restaurant was that they brought all the dishes at once whereas I would have preferred to stagger them throughout the meal. tripadvisor.ca/ShowUserR...

XfHXBh6eCkvUHQhwt6RmGw.text: We ordered the crab wontons, pad Thai, bbq Pork buns, potstickers, shrimp fried rice, and Mongolian beef. Everything was cooked to perfection and very flavorful. Every time we come to Vegas, this is our go to spot and will continue to be.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Potstickers, BBQ Pork Buns, Crab Wontons

_KzAzqOshf6ByfAccp1wkA.text: It was a very  nice meal. The food was really good, fresh food nothing pre prepare. The low main was the Bomb and the green beans were to die for.  The staff was 5*** start, very help full and understanding of the menu. Also the beer was nice and cold. I got to taste the "lucky buddha"  it was a nice choice, light beer not overpowering. And the best thing was the price. I felt it was relative inexpensive for the amount of food we got.

uZXmq4im7YV05VPP0y93-Q.text: Last night I went to dinner there with my fiance and his brother. I will say that the food was very good. We had Peking duck and kung pao chicken. The problem was that the service was awful. I felt very rushed by our server and our food came out before our drinks. How does Peking duck come out before three cocktails????? When I pointed out that we didn't have our drinks the excuse was that the bar was very busy. Well it didn't look like any of the other tables had that problem. Sorry but for a restaurant that's supposed to be high end the service was not very good.

GBWkFExJiaOjarf0prbCaA.text: We dropped in for a late night (10pm) dinner on a Monday and really enjoyed Red8. Dumplings and spring rolls were good. The Singapore noodles and Mongolian beef were excellent. As with all Wynn restaurants, there is a good if not great wine list. The decor was real nice with some tables looking out to the casino floor.  Tip: The corner 6 top has a $300 minimum.

d_KdgagvrXns8sYG0mb3OA.text: Average. The only words that completely describes my experience here. The ambiance is dull, not decorated much. It looks like a random cafe apart of the hotel. A Chinese restaurant in Las Vegas, in my opinion has the ultimate opportunity to decorate, make themselves stand out. Not be so bland.   The price range was decent. I'm actually a bit surprised it wasn't as expensive as I was expecting it to be. The average cost of a dish is 20.00 dollars. Very affordable!   OHH how could I forget what pissed me off upon arrival. I was wearing high waisted jeans. And an adorable crop top from free people. Possibly an inch of my belly was showing, (mind you I'm 28 & a nurse). The hostess pointed me out, and said "ohh you can't enter, your stomach is showing." I looked her dead in the eye and moved my shirt down the one inch, like really? Then she got all giggly. Maybe you guys should realize I'm not some hooker & calm the fuck down over one inch of skin. This is VEGAS how on earth would they even have such a stupid rule like that when crop tops are a major fashion trend.   Now moving onto the food, just average. Orange chicken was okay, chewy, a little rough/dry. The first set of noodles we ordered "Hong Kong noodles" were very strange, they had a Gooey texture. We returned it for a different dish. The walnut prawns were the best thing we ate, only dish that stood out to me.   Overall this is an average restaurant. Due to the dress code BS I won't return for sure. The food is okay, service okay.

6JY08rCFrckDN8T6GTsNUg.text: Pretty frustrated. I'm sitting in the restaurant writing this review. I was excited to have some GOOD or above average Asian cuisine. I should have also looked at Yelp prior. Both didn't happen.   I am staying as a guest in the Wynn and have many times before. I wanted to grab a quick late lunch prior to going out and eating at SW later. So that's two places I'm deciding to spend my money out of the hundreds and thousands of places to go on the strip.   I got the crab rangoons, lettuce wraps, and Mongolian beef and a drink. First of all, the crab rangoons were actually good. No issues there. The Mongolian beef was ok and good spice level. PF Changs has better lettuce wraps and bigger portions than Red 8. I also waited over 8 minutes for water refill and had to flag down a waiter to get me it. I was checked up on one time and almost just left alone my entire visit. There were 3 people standing by the walls and staring at everyone, but must have forgot me. Service and lack of food taste/quality for price is the main reason for the low rating.   I'm pretty annoyed that 2 appetizers, an entree and one drink came to $71 for mediocre food. Overpriced food that doesn't satisfy my is my biggest pet peeve especially that I have thousands of choices. I wasn't raving when I left. I absolutely love the Wynn, it is my favorite hotel in all of LV, but Red 8 missed the mark for me.  There were also gnats and a few flies that came by our table which is interesting since it's tucked away and I never see any of that throughout the rest of the casino.  To end on a good note. The ambiance and where we sat were great. Hope SW tonight is a better experience.

jP1mK6uXF7bbtt_d_7JERw.text: Always delicious.  Can't go wrong.  I love the Wynn, and Red 8 is classy,  just like the hotel and casino Great service,  you get well taken care of here. I always get the pad thai. Enjoy!

duCaJN3oPzb8_sLm8ZX3cQ.text: Arrived to Las Vegas around 10pm.  Which sort of sucks since most restaurants or at least decent ones on the Strip close at 10, which is monumentally surprising given the nightlife and casinos.  This place was open and given it is in Wynn's Chinese themed hotel the restaurant service Chinese cuisine.  But this is not your run of the mill Chinese place that you see on the corner.  The restaurant is casual but the quality is that you would expect from a high end place.  So we came in about 10 pm.  We ordered.  Classic Hot & Sour, Miso Soup, Lettuce Wraps, Kung Pao Chicken, Mongolian Beef and Fried Rice to share.  I can't say I have had a better quality Chinese cuisine.  Unlike the neighborhood places the food was light and not hit your stomach like a ton of bricks but filling enough.  I would love to visit the place again.

yM9iMHEXn0GlrbVGTyWJBA.text: Amazing. We eat here every time we come to Vegas. The pork buns are the best ever, but literally everything is fab!

0aliiiUhcpS41IN5aMGiLA.text: Definitely a Vegas restaurant. It was supposed to be elevated Asian food and I would say it was tasty just not enough of it for the price of the food portions. When I think of dim sum, I think alot of items and variety. I always leave being full. This was the regular items just presented differently.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States

j0CTGxlQludCwbllBnmaAg.text: NYE dinner at Red 8. We wanted to stay near by and not leave our hotel. Did I expect more? Was I expecting to get my mind blown away by the food? No...I was expecting a good meal. Here's our experience with the food at Red 8. I will just pin point a few major things that made this meal bad enough that I'm writing this.  You know the look of food when it's been sitting out. Yup that's what our food looked like.  1st dish...the braised soup, okay tasty, hot(tempt)..okay start  2nd dish...salted fish fried rice...it was warm and some bites were way too salty from the salted fish.  3rd dish...crispy skin pork. It was good, tasty but again warm. The meat had that pink shine like it's was sitting around. Ugh 4th dish...spicy dumplings, not that spicy but whatever's I can always add spice. Bit into it and the meat was room tempt. SMH sad...very sad excuse for a high end restaurant in a high end hotel in Las Vegas.   I understand it's a business and many lives are affected by our comments about an establishment. I would rather not post than to post a negative review but this was ridiculous.  To put a subpar product out there for vacationers looking for good food is very disappointing.This dining experience could have been some guests only experience with Chinese food that's not fast food and Red 8 failed to show people that Chinese cuisine isn't just Panda Express (nothing wrong with PE, I eat there lol) or some cheat quality fast food joint. They put this poor quality food out as representation of Chinese food, the workers, owner(s) and the Wynn Hotel, is a shame. Those people might not want to try Chinese food again or pay a higher prices for great Chinese food when they had an experience as mine. End of rant. lol  I hope this is an isolated experience and I just got unlucky. Happy New Year and happy eating everyone!

fmUAg9RABRGy6ngnHxY9xQ.text: Food is really really really good.  Service isn't great tho.  The drinks are great as well.  Good prices

Yes-ZrAYFzVLeOS73zdYlQ.text: Solid Chinese food right in the Wynn resort. Didn't have a line to sit down. Wait-staff was fine. Food was very quickly prepared and tasted pretty authentic (wasn't too salty and couldn't detect MSG) to me. I'd definitely go again if I had a craving for Chinese food on the Strip. Be prepared for Strip prices though. Definitely above-average but not 5-stars!

NzIV2XPcjp2maqum-PfxAg.text: Check out the ceiling by the entrance!  The restaurant has a robust atmosphere and can put one in a lively mood!  The best part of the meal was dessert.  So, I'll start with what we had.  We ordered mango pudding and it was delicious!  They also had other desserts that were appealing --- lychee sorbet, coconut pudding, etc. but aside from the mango pudding, we also ordered their fried banana with ice cream. I know it's hard to mess up fried banana.  But Red 8's was fried to perfection -- not too sweet and not too soft!!!  The main dishes we had included mongolian beef and sweet and sour chicken both of which were moderately-spiced.  There was nothing extraordinary about the dishes.  I suppose they tasted comparable to chinese food from any China town, only served in fancier plates.  We also had vegetable fried rice and it was average.    Although we were in a lively mood at dinner, having spent an entire day filled with activities, the food did not necessarily sustain our mood.  I felt a little dehydrated towards the end, which is why I drank a lot of water and ate most of the desserts to neutralize the slightly-salty taste from the beef.

VIkfvjb9T1mF4gomYt0Idg.text: standard chinese food... nothing spectacular... except for the price, but youre in vegas and youre right next to the wynn casino... so i guess you have to  suck it up... anyway out of the pan fried seafood noodle, mongolian beef, and garlic bok choi, the noodles were the best, beef next, and then bok choi... oh yeah... the rice is jasmine rice which i am not a fan of... i like my rice sticky... you can order brown rice as well...

2i8rGwpwrSt3_0u8eE5Yfw.text: I was in Vegas a few weeks ago and got the chance to try 3 Asian casual dining restaurants at a couple of Vegas hotels - Red 8 (Wynn), Beijing 99 (Caesar's Palace), and Wazuzu (Encore).  Out of the 3, I would rank them the following in terms of authentic flavors and yumminess -   1. Red 8 (yummiest) 2. Beijing 99 (delish) 3. Wazuzu (boo!)  I would rank them like this in terms of value  1. Beijing 99 (good selection of entrees and price range between $12-$19) 2. Red 8 (also good selection of entrees and prices between $12-$19) 3. Wazuzu (OVERPRICE ALERT!)  Overall, I would return to Red 8 and Beijing 99 for solid PF Chang-like food with PF Chang-like prices.    The chicken stirfries at Red 8 hit the spot in the couple of dishes we ordered.  The sweet and sour pork packed a vinegary punch.  The portions are well-sized, and the wait staff was friendly.  Best of all, the entrees are mostly under $21.  That's great compared to other Vegas restaurants that have $40 entrees!  Other things on the menu that we liked - the wonton noodles, and the dim sum.  I'm sure there are other better Chinese options off the strip, but Red 8 is a solid Chinese bet if you're stuck on the Vegas strip without a car to get to decent Asian places in Vegas.

FXxXqJx1k9V-aN1faDeGYA.text: Nice restaurant inside the Wynn. It's decorated very beautifully. It's pricey but that's to be expected in Vegas. We spent $65 for lunch for 2 people. We had hot and sour soup, satay, fried rice and stir fried flat noodles. Service was friendly.

rTIruTW9HKfqKHu0u0D6MQ.text: A disappointing experience. We ordered the walnut prawns, which were dry and lacked flavor. The service was poor and our waiter did not check in with us nor refill our drinks during the duration of our meal. When he finally checked back, we had long finished the other dish, cashew chicken (which was okay), and had been surfing on our smart phones for 10 or so minutes. He then offered to get us another dish and we asked for him to take the walnut prawns (which we ate less than a third of) off the bill. This took another 10-15 minutes apparently to get his managers approval. The service was poor, the food average at best and it was somewhat pricey for what we got.

-1Elk53329Fb_bXtXg744g.text: If you're looking for affordable eats in the Wynn and are sick of the super high-end scene in Vegas this is a great fit. We tried a bunch of things but my absolute favorites were the pork and shrimp dumplings, the halibut, the deep fried chicken and the roast duck. I also loved the sake. Great service - seated right away at a great table and got our food very quickly. Nice change of scene in Vegas!

pOt9J0SyoKJM0pk6ByPy5g.text: Delicious!  And...possibly the most beautiful looking Chinese restaurant I've ever been to.  It's not cheesy at all...thank god...I didn't think it was possible.  Of course the dim sum and chow-funs are cheap as hell and delicious in SF chinatown but this is the Wynn...things simply aren't gonna be that cheap.  The food honestly is very very good!  The dim sum is pricey but you just can't complain because it is SO good and so darn pretty to look at.  No screaming ladies raiding the restaurant with their reckless driving of the carts.  And for once I don't have to SCREAM and practically attack each dim sum cart to get my hands on something I want.  Service is cordially, prompt and just right.  I had a mimosa and it was so nice to have them open the champagne bottle in front of you and pour the drink right there.  Ahhh...delicious chinese food in a beautiful setting with actual service....Wynn always amazes me! P.S.  Don't go in if you can't bring yourself to pay more than $20 a person for chinese food...it's just not that type of restaurant.

XroLcT8CwRNAhbqAW0wOog.text: We happened to be in the Wynn hotel and saw the restaurant and decided to try it out.    The whole place is decorated in red True to it's name.  The food was OK, nothing to write home about.   It was pretty expensive for what it was.  I probably will not be back.

Qm3OtOLJSsvOQmNHZ3H2HA.text: Mediocre Chinese food. I ate here with eight people of Chinese decent and from San Gabriel Valley (they know Chinese food). We ordered most of the menu and were mostly disappointed.

m7qaTBYM55ZfnXuPF3wUqw.text: I agree with the other reviews that Red 8 is very expensive for what it is.  I'm picky when it comes to Chinese food, and Red 8 does not cut it.  I've been there twice.  The first time I had a very bland braised beef noodle soup.  The second time I tried the lunch special for $18.88 (so azn).  The special came with kung pao chicken, a potsticker, and a spring roll.  The kung pao chicken tasted like lean cuisine-- painfully bland.  The spring roll looked like something I might throw in the microwave at home.  Finally, the potsticker was good-- but my meal only came with one, so big whoop.  I've also sampled the dim sum, which is good, but pricey as hell-- even for Vegas.  I think we've learned our lesson and won't be back.

GNe5EIOYVW7xdsAFU-FH-w.text: I really wanted to like this place.  I ordered the Wonton Noodle Soup in hopes of curing a crucial hangover.  The soup was average.  A little too fatty for my taste - i could see a film of it floating on top!  I tried a bite of the Mongolian Beef dish, NOT GOOD.  Way too oily and tooooooo sweet.  The only semi decent dish I tried was the taro cake from the dim sum portion of the menu. Oh and don't even get me started on the service.  The waiter was soooo slow!!!  We asked for the check and 20 minutes later, got nothing.  I finally had to get up to find our waiter and even then, I STILL couldn't find him.   I had to ask a random waitress to get our check.  We could have pulled a dine and dash on his ass and he probably would be never have noticed.  Horrendous service and very overpriced for the quality of food.  Overall a bad experience.

t3mkDpoEMiCz73qj1Pu03A.text: Beautiful dining room, friendly and attentive staff but overpriced for the food. I don't mind paying high prices, but for high quality food. Honestly I have had better chinese food for a fraction of the price. But I guess you're paying for the beautiful tables and linens so it's not fair to compare them to a hole in the wall Chinese place in the Bay Area. But then again, it's also not fair to serve mediocre food at very high prices. I think my 1 serving bowl of hot and sour soup was something like $14. But, the coffee is always fresh and delicious and they give you a crystallized sugar stick, cool! Still, we always order way too much food and still enjoy ourselves. After all this is Vegas, you come to splurge and let loose. So 4 stars for me! =)

SIk85IiBDpjpLF68D_it_Q.text: My friends and I were pleasantly surprised to run into this little gem after being told the Wynn buffet wait was 45 minutes!    I had been craving some sort of Asian Cuisine after a drunken night at one of the clubs and  I passed a Chinese restaurant on the cab ride back to the hotel.  They had a nice drink selection...I wound up order a pineapple mojito!  Sounds weird to have a Cuban drink at an Asian restaurant.   We ordered two entrees and two appetizers and shared them between three people.  The shrimp won tons were the best!  Definitely check it out while you are in Vegas!  It's worth it:)

vXAeyt6R7z5gNtJ2dEK2dA.text: Dim sum was pretty good.  Get the shrimp/mushroom selection.  Dim sum extended menu not available every day, I believe only Mon-Fri.  It's chinese food, so slightly oily, but I did love the chinese broccoli.  Espresso was very good and I like the presentation (comes with candied sugar on a stick).  A decent lunch choice.

Krsgcvjw5CzB1nSFMe-ULA.text: Ive had a couple of meals here after flying into vegas for a one day trip on the lear jet.  Its the next best thing to having real dimsum in Monterey park,  and the prices for 4 pieces of shumai is triple.  But when the casino pays for your food, i guess it doesnt matter and were ordering the abalone.  The food is good here, its not excellent, and the best ive ever had.  Its good.  The service is not great, and there are times when you sit there with an empty glass.  Then why not bash the hell out of this place?  Because there arent alot of dimsum places in LV, and their egg custard buns for dessert are delicious.  Its quite the redeeming factor.

rWBopAQzdQs57tUX0B3HVA.text: We had a delicious dinner in their semi-private room in the front of the restaurant. The service was pretty good, especially in light of the fact that our group of six was a few cocktails deep by the time that we were seated. We ordered mostly dim sum type food and everything was delicious. Nothing particularly stood out. The prices were reasonable and the wine list was good. We had three bottles and probably ten dishes and the bill came to $230 or something like that. Not bad for 6 people in Vegas.

aYJGPVpWVIwUpqayia5QdQ.text: Since Wana did me the honor of writing a long review, a could cut mine short (see Wana L.).  Went here for my bachelorette dinner and the decor and ambiance was very chic and modern.  It's a pretty small restaurant, but we got the best seats right alongside the window (with no glass) to observe passerbys or for them to observe us 12 girls.  The food was family style and we had ordered boky choy, kung pao shrimp, mongolian beef, ma pao tofu, and penang noodles.  My favs were the mongolian beef, penang noodles, and the kung pao shrimp.  Portions were pretty big.  My friends also loved the bok choy but wished they would cut the pieces a bit smaller because they were hard to chew.  If you like PF Changs, it is similar to that type of "Chinese" cuisine where it's an attempt to recreate Chinese dishes with a modern twist.  Service was A plus and I even received 2 complimentary desserts: coconut ice cream and a mango pudding/custard. I don't like coconut and the mango dish was confusing - some of the party said it tasted like "refrigerator".  If that sounds confusing, imagine something you left uncovered in the fridge for a few days.  In any other city, this might stand alone because of the concept and decor, but here in Vegas it's not quite cutting it.

BURQ1nAQczaZ1mlcLqDzRw.text: The price is not worth the quality. When you pay $8.00 min for a plate dim sum you expect a lot more than what I got. The food was Mediocre at best. And what is up with charging $7.5 per person for tea? WTF!!!!!

3udLJf8E6oq3Z2WsqBSyfA.text: Came to the Wynn for the buffet but with a 2 hour wait, we decided to eat here instead. Service was ok but a little slow. We came with a group of 8. We ordered around 10 dishes total and asked the server if it was enough food. He assured us it would be but alas it was not. The food itself is pretty tasty but the portion size left us all wanting for more. Pan fried noodles and the roast duck were the two dishes that particularly stuck out in my mind.  It might be unfair to compare this place to more authentic chinese restaurants in LA but can't help it, sorry.

1N6T1kAurnNnL_bSIkLrRw.text: I made a special request - ordering something that wasn't exactly on the menu. Got exactly what I wanted and food quality was excellent.

zy8S3gT1p72L06xEUkrK0A.text: What happened to this place? It was a favorite and each time we came to Vegas it was a must. This time I ordered soft shell crab which was inedible. I ended up sharing my husband's orange beef which wasn't much better. It was overcooked, tough and oversauced (probably to cover up the first 2 problems). Very disappointing and we won't be returning or recommending this restaurant to our friends.

S1d51QV5GdsY9f_JTvMpaw.text: Great dining experience at the Wynn hotel. This restaurant was private and service was superb, the cherry on top was the showstoppers drink! Try it you will not regret it.

jxxx9I5OC6r2vk3MI-aMRg.text: As we were super hungry and didn't want to walk around much, this is the closest restaurant to the Suites Tower.  We decided to eat here.  The wait time was just few minutes.  The hostess was pleasant and helpful.  We ordered: Plum Wine - Delicious!                    Oxtail Soup - Perfection!!! 6IfCD5r2ZkRsIfz5nrt26A.text: My favorite in Las Vegas. Love the Wynn and love this restaurant. Caters to a sizable Chinese clientele in Vegas and I feel at home here. Faves are the abalone congee(warning the amount of abalone is small), roast duck, and cold ginger chicken with jellyfish. Service is attentive without being oppressive; prices are moderate.

od7yXpXhP5URdH6yE3STIg.text: This restaurant is over priced and extremely shitty quality. I ordered the cashew chicken (vegan) for 17$ and it was so bland. The sauce wasn't good, there were huge chunks of celery which would've been fine had they not been raw or maybe sliced more thin and  the fake chicken was dry (HOW DO YOU EVEN FUCK UP FAKE CHICKEN!?!) I ate like two bites of it and when asked how it was I told my waiter it was extremely disappointing and I didn't want it. My boyfriend still paid for it and I left hungry and upset.   I was excited because I know the Wynn has vegan options but NO THANKS, never again.

K2A-NPKZUe3QAEO_J7KT-w.text: Don't get their milk tea. Taste like water, the boba taste like glue soaked in water.

dkMic-F6aiOWf5tsxbnSJA.text: Nice to see that Red 8 is still going strong, with ever changing dining options on the strip.   Came on Sunday night and was quoted 20 min wait for two, which held True, I killed time watching dancing fountains sputter to the Sinatra B side and Disney tunes outside.   I am a big fan of roast duck noodles, the soup version, and though it wasn't on the menu, they happily fulfilled my request without hesitation, even asked if I wanted duck deboned- yes, please!   For appetizer we got fried soft shell crab- pure indulgence, deep fried and calorie laden, with jalapenos and roasted garlic, delicious!   I also had jasmine tea, which was a very nice flavor, and dessert of lemon grass pannacota. I love pannacota and love lemon grass, and though I never, ever order dessert, I couldn't resist. I thought it was delicious, though could have done without topping of chopped mango and strawberry, that was kind of a sloppy afterthought.   Service was spotty, a bit slow and some people around us got impatient.   All in all, you can certainly get Chinese food for less than $100 for two (no alcohol), so it's a once in a while indulgence.

Q18Fv1oprS_vFM2xko8IVw.text: I came here with my in-laws who were visiting from India and were so freakin' tired of pasta, raw vegetables, and cheese.  Oh, America.  I tried to tempt them with Japanese food at Mizumi but raw fish wasn't up their alley, either.  We stumbled across Red 8 and their eyes lit up.  Pan-Asian, it was!  As a vegan, I was absolutely delighted to be dining at a Wynn restaurant, knowing there would absolutely be delicious food for me to eat.  I started with a soy Thai Iced Tea and I nearly lost my mind, it was so good.  I ordered two vegan dim sums, the white lotus and jade dumplings, at the waitress' suggestion.  I don't remember what's actually in them (spinach?  mushrooms?) but they were both fantastic.  For my main, I had the Vegan Tofu Shiitake.  It was okay, but a little boring!  We had some hot chili paste with the dumplings so I liberally spooned that over my food to give it some oomph.  Even boring tofu and mushrooms can still hit the spot, and I left quite full.  My in-laws loved their food and everyone had a great meal.  The prices are exorbitant but nothing worse than any place else in the area.  Next time I'm in the area and craving something similar, I think I'll have to check out Wazuzu.  Similar menu, but more vegan options (including sushi!).

n2GdSCGuLunCuBQix4wnKw.text: Red 8 is just plain "ok" however having potential to be at a next level..its just short of being good.. Not quite sure what it is.. could be the seating,, could be the fact that the casino is right there and that wiff of cigarette smoke is following you into the dining area..However, If you are on this side of the strip and in need of some chinese food, this place will quench that need.  Service was very friendly and just enough. Prices are high for chinese food but thats expected in a restaurant of a major hotel like the Wynn. Entrees average $20 and up and this is a sharing type restaurant so expect to get a minimum of 2-3 dishes for a table of 2 people..  The food options here are very typical of what you would find in your hometown go to chinese spot. You can expect to find here the usual wok fried noodles, fried rice to the kung pao chicken.. They also over dim sum and noodle soupl..   Go here to quench a need but if you are looking to be wowed maybe look at some other options.

O_CagUHJZsPb9TxNokehUw.text: Despite all of the harsh reviews on here lol We enjoyed our food very much.  The ambiance was nice and our waiter was absolutely accommodating.  When we went,it was crowded and mostly everyone dining were Asians, and if the food wasn't good or close to how it should taste, you probably wouldn't see them there eating.  I think some ppl may be disappointed because they are chasing the Panda Express taste, Red 8 won't deliver that.    We ordered the XO String beans (excellent XO flavor), Yangzhou Fried rice (lots of shrimp and good flavor), HK style Wonton Egg noodle soup, Mapo Tofu (excellent flavor) and Pork & Preserved Egg Congee.  These were all finished between 2 adults and a child!  It tasted just as good as you can get in Rosemead or Monterey Park, except of course at a much higher price, but its a given when you dine inside the hotel.  For now from the 5 dishes we had, they get 4 stars.  We will definitely be back again next time on our stay and try more.

rPcZdzuWHmu-Zx_rYnKjWw.text: If you're okay with mediocre Chinese food with great ambiance and impeccable service, you will fair well here.  My bf & I were hungry, and this place looked enticing thanks to the interior design.  We may come back again for convenience sake, but it isn't at the top of our list.  Coming from the bay area and growing up Chinese, the food here is decent but far from authentic and lacks great flavors.    Mykl was our friendly waiter and delivered great service to us.  We had a couple bottles of sake which did not disappoint, ox tail soup, bok choy with scallop sauce, cold cucumbers and chicken and jelly fish.    The ox tail soup was the best.  It was pretty simple with green onions floating around and a decent portion of oxtail.  The meat didn't fall off the bone though.  The baby bok choy was okay but the scallop sauce wasn't live with flavors.  The same went for the chicken and jellyfish.  This dish had light flavors to it but once again nothing exciting.  The chicken was soft and the jelly fish was fresh.  I didn't care for the cold cucumbers much.  I thought they would be more soy sauce and garlicky, but they had a ginger sweetness to them I didn't care for.  My bf liked them fine though.  Honestly, PF Chang's serves better Chinese food, but I'm sure there are other things on the menu I might like better.  The red and black decor with dramatic lighting is absolutely top notch design, but that and the service here is all you will find to be exceptional.

O2yjR1bNGbrSAkuxOe_eCA.text: Not as good as I expected. The quality of the foods are just ok. Some of them are too salty. Also the service needs to be improve.

EJxL5NNLVhEug7x0UOD-Iw.text: I don't know why it has good rating. This restaurant looks beautiful and very Chinese, but I didn't get good service. I wanted to get some water but I didn't get it until 30 minutes I finished my dinner. No one asked me if we were ok. Also, the food was not very good. We ordered steamed fish, beans, beef and dessert, and the only thing acceptable for me was the fish. I don't like the beef. It was not juicy enough and it was quite dry and old.

RAZzWlNQUO6RgpordyEzlw.text: Price and value. I really don't mind to pay for $40 per person for lunch in a 5 star hotel in Vegas ..but rude service (waitress to be EXACT) dropped the value. I seldom spent time on social media but this is the worst experience I ever had in Vegas. I should have read some review before I stepped in this 3.5 star restaurant.   We came here with my younger kids and we werent exactly sure of the menu as we were unfamiliar with some words. Our waitress already had that judgmental vibe from the start. Didn't care to explain when we asked her.  Me: "What is Har Gow?"  Waitress (name starts with "D") : "Its Dumpling" --with duh! attitude and facial expression...uhh yeah we see that, its what it says in the menu.  Hoping she would elaborate more but nope.   Me: So what's difference between Har Gow and Shanghainese dumpling ? Waitress (name starts with "D") : "Both steamed" ---- thank you.....    The service was absolutely terrible and we felt really rushed to order, eat and pay our checks. Our waitress abruptly took plates away without really asking.   Is Vegas really lack of nice and knowledgeable people to work in hotel industry ??? This waitress should be out of her job the first day she work in any hotel in San Fransisco. Her attitude and the way she answered each questions were pointless.  Feel bad with the rest of the team in this restaurant, Dim Sum was not bad, seems better than some good Chinese restaurant in SF, one black sheep can got a team down. Management should do something.   NEVER coming back to this place....STAY AWAY!!! or if you wanna challenge this waitress, go and find out if my word is correct. lol

CHPavs3o7jslq-rXTirvlg.text: You come to the Wynn to have a great resort experience and dining experience as well.    The food here was medicore at best and the prices were hefty.  Not to mention service was non existent for most of our meal even with the restaurant not being that busy.  Our waitress came to our table and had a scowl on her face with no smile in sight.  I'm not a politeness snob from wait staff usually but if you look at us unhappily I will notice.    They also got our order incorrect, we ordered the beef tofu and they gave us ma po tofu.   We ordered mongolian beef here and the portion was tiny!  I paid almost $20 for it and the ingredients weren't top notch and the portion was low.   Needless to say you can find better Chinese and/or asian options nearby.
