0jPIo25g_hZ-XKHLsLPUSA.text: Close to the worst restaurant ever. Shrimp penang & beef dan dan were bland and tasteless and tasted exactly the same. I had to spit the shrimp out it tasted spoiled and my dining mates said the beef had a rainbow sheen. We returned all 3 dishes after 1 bite. I will say, the vegetarian chik'n lettuce wraps were ok. Overall, a waste of a 45 minute wait. Do yourself a favor & avoid this place.

b0S18ENdLJ6peQBQfjk1Ww.text: We really llked the food we had on Saturday April 19. We did not know about Red and had seen this in the hallway wondering what it was. The large tables at the bench seating area as well as the large central tables require that people practically shout to reach each other. I did not appreciate being in the midst of such a noisy place.  Staff were wonderful. Michael the waiter was superb! I had the eggplant and pork (although they serve pork belly and have to explain that to you, it is not on the menu which I think is wrong) with cat's eye noodles. It was delicious. I would have preferred to have pork as stated on the menu though. My husband enjoyed the Kung Pao shrimp very much.  He is a tough critic and stated it was one of the best meals ever. We shared the chicken satays which were among the best I have had and the peanut sauce was texturally superb and seasoned perfectly. I am not ever a fan of bench seating but although you are not totally on top of people next to you on the bench, you are so far away from your dining partner that it is very weird and not pleasing at all.  We were seated near a bunch of twenty somethings under the influence of alcohol whose voices even sober were obnoxious... Next time I would surely choose Red 8 and I would insist on a regular table away from that style of seating. We were impressed by the reasonable prices. Tasty but Noisy.

DNEa6iwWVgLyMsDUscwHOw.text: My goto place for Hong Kong regional style dining. This is as authentic as it gets outside of Asia for True "local" Hong Kong crispy beef noodles, chicken feet, and siao long bao (soup dumplings).  Regional delights are also good, with Singaporean style chicken satay, Singapore street rice noodles, Cantonese roast duck, and traditional Hong Kong style wonton mien.  The only thing lacking, which is a weird thing to say since I'm touting authenticity, is the same sometimes-annoying Hong Kong service. Sometimes they fuck up your order and the one thing you've been craving some turns gets lost in limbo.  Still, I'll take that over better service with shitty food.

XZiVTakybKVXLVoilFSOMg.text: Fast Chinese restaurant that serves standard Asian food. I like how this place also has specialty teas. I get the lychee green tea.   Food: their hot and sour soup is very good  Main entree: I get the Mapo tofu here. Sometimes they have lunch specials where I got a braised pork belly. They change often so check back. This place gets very crowded.

M2bhIv6kBX3neAI6PrNCWA.text: Decided to try this place since we stayed at Encore and it was convenient. My two friends ordered the beef noodle soup and I ordered the sweet and sour chicken with a side of brown rice. Everything tasted good, but I don't think there was anything special about the food where I'd want to go out of my way to come back. The sweet and sour chicken came out crispy and fresh and it wasn't overly sweet to me. It had the right amount of tangy-ness you'd expect. The beef noodle soup was also good, the noodles weren't overcooked and the beef was tender. Service was good and the restaurant was very clean. Prices are a little steep (came out to around $25 for my sweet and sour chicken with a side of rice) but it's Vegas. Overall a solid 3/5.

8w7VFz-ZmrFX0xwsrhPKrg.text: I had the Curried Singapore fried noodles, it was spicy and full of flavor. Service was average.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I had the Curried Singapore fried noodles, it was spicy and full of flavor. Service was average.

QCQmM_kGfre7ppytUKqo3Q.text: Take it from an actual Chinese person. Honestly... not bad!  I cringed as we entered this over-the-top fancy Asian fusion restaurant inside the Wynn. On the menu I saw Japanese edamame but also Chinese dumplings. Oh boy. Here we go.  Cracked open the menu and cringed even more at the prices... Chinese food is supposed to be cheap. What the hell is this $20 chow mein and $9 for 3 dumplings? Whatever, we were crunched on time and needed to eat at the hotel before going out. Also we are at The Wynn. Oh yeah also we are in VEGAS ANYWAYS MOVING ON-  Service was extremely slow (or maybe because we were in a hurry) but after you order, the food comes out really fast. We had a 30 minute wait at 8:30pm last Friday night. We were done eating by 9:45pm.  Here's what I remember ordering (for a party of 6): - xiao long bao (skip it. they have no idea what they're doing here. as expected) - bok choy with scallop sauce - chow mein with beef (surprisingly delicious tender beef. I expected it to be stale) - shiu mai - green beans with garlic (fantastic) - bbq pork buns a.k.a. cha siu bao (surprisingly authentic) - sweet and sour pork   Food came out piping hot and very flavorful and authentic enough. There's nothing that makes my skin crawl more than offensive adaptations attempted by capitalist America at the food of my motherland.  But I gotta say. I was impressed and YES I would eat here again.  Bill came out to about $22 per person.

UWdNyetSb_xyweBK16rgIQ.text: If you are staying at the Wynn and are starving for some Asian dishes, Red 8 is a great place to tame those cravings. Prices are actually double compared to regular Asian restaurants. However, you are paying for the convenience, location on the Strip (Wynn), and ambiance.  We had the Salt and Pepper Calamari, Stir-Fried Mixed with Chinese Vegetables, and Egg Noodles with Beef mixed with Soy Sauce. I really enjoyed the fact that all these dishes were reminiscent of authentic dishes that I would normally find at a regular Chinese restaurant. The service and cuisine at Red 8 was excellent. I would recommend coming here for a casual Asian lunch or dinner if you are staying at the Wynn.

tnAgnSuNlAAU60mMxeAzLw.text: They deserve 6 stars. The oxtail soup is da bomb dot com! So delicious. And the service was very on point. I have been to China so I feel like my opinion matters. I really liked the decor. I sat on the red seats, they look like couches. So comfy. I plan to come back.

_4i5RI0GE2itLnQC-3kS1w.text: Food here is amazing! They also have a small menu for dim sum and they are good! I love their noodle soup. They open for lunch and dinner daily. I will definitely come back again.

I feel like Red 8 was cheaper compared to the other restaurants I went to Vegas.       We went around 2noon and it wasn't busy a lot of vacant tables. As soon as we sat down our waiter came and greater us and took drink orders. He was very attentive and made sure everything was ok. The food was nothing spectacular just your regular Americanized Asian cuisine. I ordered the combination fried rice which was pretty good. Our food came out in a timely manner which is great! It was a good portion and very filling. I also got a pomegranate martini which was just OK, I've had better.       Our sever didn't really engage in conversation he just did everything by the book leaving no lasting impression. It's probably Management and not him.

kxkrFzyhlkua7v1MoBo77w.text: A nice place for causal dine out. Authentic Chinese flavor. Cannot go wrong with any appetizer, dim sum, noodles or soups. Fair price; if you are not looking for a formal place like Wing Lei, Red 8 is where you can get some awesome food. Same taste with the Red 8 at Wynn in Macau. Highly recommend.

BpbCv0O6fv-p1CHNwlajgw.text: My biggest issue with this place was the pretentious hostess who kept coming around to tell us something about our kids and giving us the stink eye anytime the kids made any noise.   The cucumber cup cocktail was water down juice.  For $16 I wanted a hard hitting drink.. not something I can make in my nutribullet.   The food was great. The chicken kung pao was a little too spicy for our 80 year old guest but good for us.   The service needs some help too.. should be more attentive for the pricey restaurant, because after all we opt for sitting down restaurant over buffet for the service and ambiance.

_xDSizP4P3PkisYASbvnHA.text: Red 8 has all of the signs of a Chinese establishment I would run away from: + Gaudy red lacquered wood and over the top Asian theme  + Las Vegas strip location + Small portions + Hefty price tag  ... but, I love my unborn child and he apparently has a big taste for dumplings so I barely flinched when I saw the $10 price tag for two tiny pork bbq bao at this Wynn establishment. Besides it was my best friend's 30th birthday weekend so it was time to treat yo'self!  After a day of raisin-ing ourselves by the pool we were starving for some rice and noodles. Sure Chinatown was just an Uber away but this was right in our hotel so we decided to check it out. We immediately decided to get an order of Shanghai soup dumplings, pork bbq bao and pan fried shrimp bao as well as some crispy seafood egg noodles. As I mentioned, the dim sum came in very small portions with high price tags but it was totally worth it. The pork bao had the softest, fluffiest bun I've ever tasted and a perfect ratio of meat to dough. They actually had this dish at the Wynn buffet down the road, but it did not compare to the taste of this by miles. I had never had a pan fried bao before, but it was an amazingly crispy texture that just melted when it hit your mouth.   I'd skip the soup dumplings but I loved how each one was presented in a tiny mini bamboo basket to minimize breakage (they left the wax paper on so be careful of that!). Egg noodles were delicious but no more delicious than what you would get at another good Chinese restaurant in anywhere, America.   Service was friendly and they also sell bubble tea which was nice to grab to go during the rest of our pool days!

slNgn6RMGoacwZIJtqc-ZQ.text: This place is amazing. Some of the best dim sum I have ever had and I have had a lot of dim sum!!! The egg noodles with beef in soya sauce was delicious as was the steamed bbq pork buns and prawn dumplings. The staff was very nice as well. Highly recommend! Hidden gem on the Vegas strip!!!!!!

RCijt2cfle4GYRxiEHoftg.text: This is the best place to get sushi in the entire city. Me and my buddies Steve and Eric came here and got thousands of dollars worth of sushi comped. It was amazing. We all sat under the cabana and then ended up here. Steve made me and Eric get him a sandwich but it was cool because Steve is a little quirky. That's just the price of hanging out with Steve. I took my mom to the doctor beforehand. I'm sorry? I mean she's okay. Do you really want the background on her? She grew up in the depression. Marilou got a hundred thousand dollars from Steve in the Philippines. People say she's Australian but she's really Philippino at the base.

Ar0Pv7VuSPmKLtZZ3AxiRQ.text: Service is a hit and miss.    Yesterday - Waiter was great even though they were busy.   Today - Waiter didn't even bother to drop by after ordering and not busy.  But the servers were great. Wish I can only tip the servers.  Food is good, expensive but acceptable for Vegas.

nMA7WySa6WPpYmj0pJaf8g.text: If there is only one thing you take away from this review, it is to stop by and get the Thai iced coffee to-go. It's amazing!! Imagine if Thai tea and Vietnamese coffee had a baby, that's what their Thai iced coffee tastes like. I have had this beverage many times elsewhere, but nowhere else is it as perfect as it is here. If I could have this coffee everyday, I would.   Moving on ...   It was good, but not blow-your-mind good. For how much you're paying, this should be the best damn dim sum you've ever had. Their dim sum is a little better than average. I will say, everything tasted fresh.   Don't be discouraged if you don't see something on their dim sum menu - the full menu isn't provided. Out of curiosity we asked if they had certain items that weren't listed, and they were able to accommodate us. Off menu dishes: sauteed Chinese broccoli, soup dumplings, Thai iced coffee, and ha cao.   Overall, good dining experience, just not really worth the hefty price.

4W9bki1okxJBHlC1PJ-IeQ.text: Really liked the look of this place and some of the tables have a cool layout. The food however doesn't come close to the ambiance. I got the crispy pork belly and let me tel you ITS CRISPY! in fact so crispy it's inedible. Others at my table got a couple chicken dishes and they weren't happy either. I had a taste and they were right the chicken tasted "off". The only thing that wasn't bad was the noodles we got. Overall we left unsatisfied...the next day we tried TAO and it was such a great experience and better value it reminded us of how bad the food at Red 8 was haha! I would check it out if you just want a place with a good look to grab something small and chat, definitely not for dinner.

_d7hM-Reu_nF3MUSng2hZg.text: What a surprisingly affordable meal in a place that really doesn't offer cheaper alternatives.  They food was good, with some surprisingly great dumpling offerings.  In comparison the the alternate Asian offering in this hotel - go to Red 8.  Not a lot of difference in the menus (generic type Asian fusion) but this one is at least half the price.  Coming from an Asian dominated culture, this type of food shouldn't be ripping a hole in your pocket and Red 8 doesn't.

iLvvewxovA1L1HegvNKXpg.text: It was another dinner visit to Red 8, this time with another couple in tow, resulting in a reprised 4-1/2-star dining experience!  This time a bowl of classic Hot & Sour Soup was suitably spicy but not overbearing;  Shrimp & Pork Dumpling Noodle Soup was quite nice, as was a lightly sweet Almond Shrimp Dumpling that was covered with almond shavings formed into the shape of small shields.    Honey Prawns featuring honey glazed walnuts and large shrimps were just sweet enough, while lengths of Beef Tenderloin with Black Pepper Sauce and Black Mushroom added were hot and tender bathed in a nice peppery sauce.    A scoop of Strawberry Sorbet diminished some of the flames, and provided a refreshing palate cleanser as a fine finish to my meal.  Service was excellent, and the Asian ambiance elegant and sumptuous, yet casual in attitude and tone.

kglDsxd-iZvJlZTrrClwmw.text: The service was horrible! We are staying at the Wynn and they promoted this place in an article in our room. The spareribs were small little individual ribs. $25.00 for combination fried rice? There was no seafood in the rice. I am giving it 2 stars cause my husband said his oxtail soup was good. Can I say the service is bad again! They were slow with preparing our dinner. We waited 45 mins on the reservation list, they were supposed to text us, and they didn't we had to come back and ask if our table was ready. Once we sat, we waited over 45 mins four our food.  The portions are also small.  I just do not recommend them.

Iglgko-nJGBjSfsT8D_vcw.text: I love the location of this restaurant. Wynn is one of my favorite hotels and the atmosphere and vibe is great! I wasn't thrilled worth the service, very slow to take our order and then get the check at the end. If they were busy, I'd understand but they have a whole 5 tables there.  I also didn't like that the food wasn't spread out. They brought soup and appetizers out at the same time and before we could even finish, the main course came out. Big minus. I like my food to be timed a bit better.  We ordered the shrimp dim sum and the crab Rangoon as appetizers, both were delicious. The hot and sour soup was very flavorful and had a nice kick to it.  As main course, it was suggested to get one dish to share since portions are large. The chefs special included seared scallops so we went with it. It is not a dish to share. 6 small scallops were served with a small salad and brown rice. I wasn't thrilled with the scallops. They didn't have much flavor and he side salad had no dressing. As a whole, I wasn't impressed. I heard great things, so I wouldn't mind trying it again with more traditional dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Crab Rangoon
Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shrimp dim sum

DlcgbcD0HFsDGPwHciUzAQ.text: We stayed at the Wynn and so I liked the convenience of this restaurant and the service was good.  I ordered the potstickers as an appetizer and the shrimp pad thai.  Both were delicious- especially the appetizer!  I just was kind of blown away with the gigantic portion of the pad thai.  I could not finish it all but I would rather have that experience than be left hungry.  The only bad thing was that we didn't have a microwave while staying at the Wynn so I couldn't take the food to go.

rR_NobqVSGyZxb6_phKy8g.text: We had a small birthday dinner for a friend last night.  Each person had different items. The food was ok, portions were on the small side. Our waiter was ridiculous when asked 'what do you recommend?' Reply ' Everything' . I had never eaten there so I thought everything would be good and flavorful.  Wrong. As for service, you would think being at the Wynn that service would be good. Again WRONG. I had something spicy and it took a very long time for the server to bring a refill of water. Had to get up and wave him down. Not a good experience but that where the birthday girl wanted to go.

3rUhDfGlx_rqoRMnmldMmQ.text: I like that I'm not running for a gallon of water after eating here.    The pork & preserved egg congee really hit the spot and EVERY spoonful had ingredients swimming in it.  Very rare to see that.    Jasmine tea $7 Congee $12 Shu Mai $7 Potstickers $7 Chicken Chow mein $16  There is other Chinese on the strip that tastes better, but this cures the fix.

XrmmIeDGd3jkdaZLip0zjA.text: I'll start by saying they have a good amount of stuff on the menu here from the Wynn Macau so the food is pretty authentic.   My favorite dish here are the Hong Kong Crispy Noodles. The noodles are really good and they don't smother it in cheap xo sauce.   The downside to this place is that they don't take reservations and they like to pretend they're busier than they actually are. I would recommend putting your name down, coming back, and not accepting their "you weren't back fast enough" excuse they might try to hand out (as in my case). Vegas is all about False scarcity. Don't take it! On the flip side, actual food service was very good. I would come here again!

Q8TAehWOVEuHBkC00sEubA.text: Red 8 is located in the Wynn Hotel & Casino and is a very charming "Red" Asian inspired restaurant.    We had the Crab claws $10 for 2 pieces expensive but  tasty, Mongolian Beef $21 and Fried Rice Chicken & beef $18.  I enjoyed the ambiance and the food was decent.    Service was great they checked on us often to make sure everything was to our satisfaction and to see if we needed water, drinks, etc...

bWKb92oAYS6tDyuBCv7Dww.text: I was excited to try red 8 , because I love Asian food. The food was below average and the service was worse. I was very disappointed with my food which was Kung pau chicken. Also the soup I ordered hot and sour soup was neither hot or sour. I will not be visiting this location again because it was overpriced and the food and service were not good.

SzgsrsCTClRq0ZjRcuC5Hw.text: This place is amazing! We always make a point to stop here when we are in town. They have wonderful vegan options and everything is so tasty. Wait staff are very friendly.

WYtJ9Pao0Mh_pLjVtD3Tug.text: Let me start by saying that I ate here at lunchtime with my husband and our three kids.   Our kids are young, but we eat out A LOT, so they behave well and generally enjoy good food.  They seated us quickly and were very attentive throughout the meal--I would give the service 5 stars.  The food, though?  The food.  The food is eh.  Fine.  We ordered a lot.  Edamame, bbq pork buns, lots of different dumplings--pork, shrimp, chicken.  We had chicken fried rice, Kung Pao Chicken and Mongolian Beef.  There were no standouts.  The dumplings tasted homemade and fresh but were still just ok.  The chicken and beef entrees were a step up from Panda Express, but a step down from other Chinese restaurants I've eaten at.  Like I say, nothing bad at all.  So go to Red 8 if you want a meal that's just fine.

adFE79QjRhZ2dNY-lhk-cg.text: Hm. If u just want something to eat. Fare place to go. But speak loud, the young man here seems can't hear very clear, and don't expect to much about the food, just less tasty food.

q1K2IsublommYTuOMXCWVw.text: As for Chinese food "Hong Kong" style, this would have to top my list of to go to Chinese food places, although price wise this ain't your fast food Spring Mountain Las Vegas Chinese restaurant.  Every dish I ordered I always enjoyed, I have been here may be 4 times and each time I have always enjoyed the food and the experience.

HSxTZ-Zigp0ttlTh7cCpqg.text: Well, It is kind of hard to find decent Chinese food on the Strip or even China Town. Somehow, in my opinion, Red 8 had pulled it off. On my most recent visit to Red 8, they had made some improvement to the quality of the food and a noticeable change can be compared to my earlier visits. For example, They no longer cook Xiao Long Bao in small foil. I also tried their pepper and salted seabass and it was heavenly. The crispy pork also taste really good and so was the duck. I recommend any patron who visited this restaurant to order to BBQ combination plate for its varieties of meat. I would definitely come back here again!!!

Photo of Red 8 - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Feets

khb6RAbrcJKP1s52y6TNJA.text: I would like to add, this was the first dining experience in Vegas. After checking in -- a 4 hour flight -- we were super hungry. This was right downstairs and you could smell the delicious food outside. The ambiance to this place was great. The service was okay. We ordered a couple of dishes and they were all great. Overall, this was a fun and relaxing experience.

6FdlbL5Wi45ASW5qxK8BSQ.text: Well, what can I say.  I didn't love this place.  The food was very good but unfortunately we couldn't keep the server's attention.  We had meals that were about $20 a plate.  I attribute that to being Las Vegas so that really wasn't off putting as much as having to beg for refills and having all four of our glasses empty and having that being ignored.  We got a to go box for our leftovers and took it back to the room.  That worked out well.    But then there was the waiting for the check and then when I immediately laid the credit card down.  Waiting for someone to take it.  A woman that worked there finally noticed as our server was elsewhere and took care of it.    I left $5 for a $70 dinner and that was probably too much because instead of staying poor service it probably simply said I was cheap.  Well, whatever.  The food was worthwhile but I don't know if I could take the slow service again.  It was definitely a convenient place while staying at the Encore.

hhs43w34bE65sLRlBgi2Kw.text: This was my first not so great food experience at the Wynn.  We've dined at all the restaurants here over the years and the experiences have been fantastic.  First time to Red 8 and the experience was... well... Our server was not interested in extending any inspiration to us about the menu.  Questions were met with quick, dismissive responses.  Ok, fine.  He wasn't rude...just not into it.  Whatever then, let's just eat... Food arrived and dish after dish things were just 'meh'.  Dim sum. Over cooked.  Mushroom dumpling was like chewing through an ear.  Baked egg custard- pastry good. Custard split and hard.  Taiwanese flat noodles with sauce.  Where is the sauce? Where's the flavor? Mongolian beef.  Tender. Good. Flavorful. Baby boy choy.  Vegetable.  Overall middle of the road experience for a hotel that usually does nothing but impress.

hRF20HiFCy0OZteg5GdY9g.text: It is Sunday in Vegas.  What a wild two nights it was.  We needed something to help clear away the cobwebs of overindulgence.  Upon arriving at the Wynn hotel we were greeted by the nicest doorman.  We walked inside and headed to Red 8.   Great food with perfect spice.  For an appetizer I had the Pork Wonton.  This is not fried but steamed.  Great flavor and excellent burn.  For an entree I had the Pork Eggplant with the hand formed "pigs ear" noodles.  I could not stop eating.  A large portion that was excellent.  Thank you.

itTB6zbG_LxPen0PdFLHnQ.text: 3.5 stars  The good is very good and the meh is pretty meh. The good -- salt and pepper sea bass, spicy wontons, most of the noodle dishes. The meh -- dan dan noodle (how can you screw up dan dan noodles?) and the dim sum.

vvUZUOFOOv7XG_tQWqNeSQ.text: I ate here for Halloween- it was pretty pleasant.  The wait staff was very entertained when we came in our costumes!  We had made reservations and we were seated underneath the gigantic crystal dragon.  The decor was very oriental yet contemporary.  Let me start of with a disclaimer though- you cannot compare this place to Wing Lei, as other reviewers have done.  Not only is Red 8 in the casual dining tier versus Wing Lei's fine dining classification, but Red 8 is meant to cater to a different crowd.  Tourists, yes, but a different type of tourist.  One who doesn't want to splurge on food, just wants something quick to eat, or wants a Pan-Asian meal because essentially, that is what Red 8 serves.  A reviewer earlier described this place pretty accurately- a Panda Express on steroids.  Just throw in some Indonesian, Thai, and Cantonese dishes in there and you're all set.  The food was pretty good- nothing stunning, but something worth its money.  I had the pineapple fried rice, which was very nice since I don't know of any other restaurant that makes that.  And actually, we were all mooching off of each others' dishes, so I can't remember everything I ate!  All I know is that I would go to Red 8 again- not too often, but if there's a small occasion to celebrate.  I'm giving this place 3 stars because of the food.  Noodles Restaurant and other casual dining restaurants that are similar to Red 8 deliver much better in terms of food.  I can't fault the service- it was flawless.  They were vibrant and worth going back just for to see them again.  Sadly, I can't say the same for the food.

Ws6nrXs069QbxrTkPQ_PDA.text: Went there again for lunch. Food was delivered not as fast as before but the service staff aware of it and kept track on our orders. Managers are nice to check on us. Service are super

le70sIJ5Be8UivzkFFVCLw.text: This place is fantastic! We've dined here several times over the years & have never been disappointed. They're open for lunch & late into the eve. making for a good choice other than the crappy 24 hr. Cafe. The food is authentic, service is great & specialty drinks are yummy!!

lqO3cAhzi2QqWNT_Yoih3Q.text: Stopped in here for a quick meal after a shopping excursion in the Wynn and left somewhat disappointed. The turnip cakes were some of the best and the Cantonese dumplings were delish but the dan dan noodles, which they note is a signature dish was beyond bizarre.  It came dry with very little by way of meat or flavor and you have the option of adding broth.  Well the broth did not add anything.  Blech.

AP6eBEv7o9-iGhx8MTf61g.text: WOW! Everything we ordered was so fresh and awesome. We wil return here again. We ate here before seeing Le Reve'. AS the show was wonderful, so was  Red 8.  Service was so exceptional. It is one of the best Asian we have eaten, in Las Vegas.

TPBznx2-LOjYvn1-cwK-Yw.text: We enjoyed everything.  Wait staff was right there with out being intrusive.  On our keeper list.

OFLq60RcWWFfyrcue0X2Lg.text: Food was good...A solid dining wxperience, but the service was a bit lacking...no staff had personality and they forgot to bring out one of our dishes...After that we had to wait 30 minutes to get a corrected bill...dine with caution

0eRztMg8QlwbvN7XA7D9ug.text: I never come to Vegas without eating here. Its usually a long wait since they don't take reservations but always worth it. LOVE

VypmMc18hsbhC4niQNkyTg.text: Came here for lunch yesterday and I really enjoyed everything :)  I thought all the flavors were a solid "Good!"  were they amazing?  No.. but it was good.  We ordered a variety of plates ranging from dim sums like sesame sweet dumplings, crab claw, shu mai, and beef noodles.  Service was efficient and drinks were delicious.  2 thumbs up!

adM_xLWQeHEyBgZwvk-R8A.text: Who loves paying $22 for chow fun? How about $25 for congee?   Me. Me. Me.   NOT.   Come on, seriously? If it tasted amazing, i'd be more than willing to pay that much. But I can get better chow fun just 5 minutes away on Spring Mountain Road or even better, at a ghetto place in Monterey Park!   Anyways, I came here yesterday for lunch. We ordered: abalone congee, yang chow fried rice, two different vegetables (not sure what the English name is, but that doesn't matter), wonton noodles, and various dim sum dishes.   The abalone congee was around $25, but the whole time I thought "where is the abalone?" I seriously think they shredded a few pieces of abalone in there to officially charge that much (..obviously). The yang chow fried rice was really delicious, I give them street cred for that one. The wonton noodles were good, but it didn't taste authentic Asian. It tasted quite Americanized, especially the soup base. Fail. As far as the dim sum goes, it was actually quite tasty -- yes, all of it. It was on the more expensive side, around $6-$12 per dim sum dish, which is actually quite expensive for dim sum.   Our bill for 4 people came out to around $120. Not bad for the Wynn. But if I went to a place in Chinatown, the same food (with the same taste, if not better) would probably have been $40 bucks. Gotta love it.

R9I2mJkWP2suAk6xWS6FWw.text: I wanted to love this place, but it's rather overpriced. The service was the worst part of the meal, as the server halfheartedly took our order and showed no enthusiasm for any recommendations. The food was good, but not amazing. I am sorry to say I won't ever be back :(

oX-o65mlHRSyKP5suHnCbA.text: Was here for lunch in October '14 and found it to be an "ok" restaurant for Vegas. The best part of the meal was the "sticky rice wrapped in papaya leaf" appetizer. Had the Black Bean sauteed Spare Ribs with Udon Noodles for main course.  Was decent but quite salty (as most American Asian food). Drinks are ridiculously overpriced ($4.50 for an Iced Tea) but such is Vegas. Service was very friendly but quite slow.  Overall, it was decent but I'd probably go try to find something new before coming back.

DwIjG_KtRFa1RcTHMRFAaw.text: can I just say, what a delightful surprise in the middle of a casino hotel! Found this gem while visiting Vegas with my sisters. We were in need of lunch but did not wish to go far as we had an evening appointment we did not want to miss! this lovely spot was exactly what we needed. We were seated right away and loved the decor. Classic red but with very modern touches. A bit of old and new China mixed.  We ordered Pad Thai and Spicy  beef. The lunch was delicious and generous portions! the price was fair and service was very good. I think I would go back here again!

3JtM5das7kb8aU5cDPBN6Q.text: I give the food 4 stars; it's pretty decent although it is pricey for what you get.  But hey, it is the Strip after all.  The service I give 1/2 star (thus the average of about 2 stars).  We watched time and again as our waiter breezed past our table, without so much as a glance toward our empty glasses, in order to pander to larger groups.  Obviously he thought he was going to get bigger tips from them...turns out he was right.  It didn't have to be that way though.    Here is my tip to the Red 8 wait staff:  Don't make the customers ask you for everything; if all their glasses are empty ask them if they need some more water or another drink.  If they would like to box up the uneaten portion of their dinner, box it all up instead of half.  Ask them if they'd like dessert or anything else before you drop the check on their table.  Most importantly, even if your opinion is to the contrary, treat them as if they deserve to be dining in your fine restaurant.

A1PAmiWYzmUgI1yC1Car6w.text: Very confusing...their Dan Dan Mien tasted like a Pad Thai, and how is it possible to make a hot & sour soup taste like tomato bisque???

dXYUFohi96QVDJvGAVe0FA.text: I highly recommend.  The food was great, the portions generous, and you couldn't ask for better service.  Also, the decor is really cool and classy.    They have a nice blend of authentic Chinese and American-style Chinese.  Finally, the price is great. I would expect to pay twice the price for half the quality around here.

wAlj6roGB3zzBlxcX5vYyQ.text: Pretty good food, not terrible pricing, at least for being inside a casino hotel. If you're looking for about $65 meal for two and are having trouble finding that in the casino, this is a pretty good option...

hXH4lib9BdQ2uOPayUu4xA.text: Why a restaurant of this quality can manage to open this long?? In Wynn some more?? When we walk into the restaurant we have to greet the hostess first instead of her greeting us.  Then it takes forever just to get our drinks. I mean, our appetisers arrived before our drink and she even ordered the wrong appetiser. If you dont want to work there then go home and send someone else.  I ordered a $22 singapore laksa because they said its their specialty. The noodles were so small portion and although the soup taste good, I realised they probably put lots of msg cos I am thirsty for the rest of the evening. My fiancee ordered an eggplant noodle and yet theres not a single eggplant in it, I think she ordered a pork feet for her instead. We are too hungry to care so we just carry on munching  on those little portion of foods.  You spent $70 and u are still hungry, man, should've gone to chinatown.   Anyway, when they delivered the bill, it was ridiculous, they put some stuff that we didnt even ordered. CHECK UR BILL BEFORE YOU PAID.  Absolutely make sure you CHECK UR BILL!!! I would never come back thats for sure. Red 8 my ass you should call urself one done!!!

iZQKfW_OBmB47ZgkPo3mxQ.text: Stopped into Red 8 after The Buffet had too long of a line. I am so glad I did! Talk about gourmet hang over food! One of the best Asian restaurants I have been to. They offer upscale American Chinese food. Since it was during the day, it felt more casual although the decor is beautiful and I can image it would be a fairly romantic spot for a dinner with all the red and black colors.   We had the Curry Vermicelli noodle dish along with the chicken satay app. We also tried the sweet & sour chicken. Everything was phenomenal and it really hit the spot! It was all that is good about eating Chinese food, but I felt less guilty since it was so obviously prepared with fresh ingredients.  Our waitress was extremely welcoming as well. I will visit Red 8 next time I am in Vegas!

sgxZBnquSYG64yMXbDTSdw.text: Suckest Chinese food ever had. Nothing tastes right. A couple of boiled tofu with soy sauce cost 10 dollars. Will not ever return here.

d0TydGchJ4YCdTrtmKS50A.text: First of all, I would like to clarify that I wanted to give 0 star, but obviously I couldn't. To reserve a table, you can't call in but have to show up in person. Then you would be asked to come back in an hour even there probably empty tables inside. After we sat down and waited for almost half an hour, no one came to serve us not even asked if we need a drink. A waitress cleaned up the table right next to us dropped a glass on the floor and the broken pieces splashed all over the floor right next to us and of course under our table. No one came to apologize. Finally, this waiter walked over to us and asked if he could take our order. We said: yes, of course. But can you please give us a glass of water please? And then he walked away without saying anything and never came back. I saw him murmured to his colleague saying something like they only wanted water! Eventually we had to walk up and asked someone else to take our order. The food was not fresh and completely overpriced compared to other nice restaurants with excellent service. After we paid the bill, the waiter came to us to take the receipt and opened it up to see how much tip we gave before we left!!! THIS WAS SO RUDE AND DISGUSTING!!!! I think I am very nice enough to leave a tip and didn't make a complaint in public. However, this was the worst service I got ever in the United States. I will never ever come back again. If you want to come and try, I will warn you DO NOT EXPECT ANY SERVICE!!!

XW3Lxti0Eb0F6Ps3ndMeyw.text: Not bad if you're hungry and are craving asian food without wanting to venture outside of the Wynn/Encore or the Vegas strip.  Pricey compared to what you can get at any other "regular" joint but this is Vegas!

sU_1DBnyWCJpqFwGrsJaKg.text: My husband and I came this place for lunch, both of us like the food here. We ordered the sea bass, which is very good! And we also like the house special ox tail soup.  Five stars for the food, three stars for the price. It's a little bit pricy, but worth to try!

kWobY0GFiz6y3lUelEc6CA.text: Imagine if you took all the best Chinese chefs from all your favorite holes in the wall and put them into one restaurant. You've got Red 8. This is Panda Express on steroids, and it is noticeably better.  Down the hall, at Wing Lei, they have a much more pretentious Chinese dining experience that will cost you four-fold. If your taste buds know and enjoy the taste of money, then feel free to take your champagne glass and handerkchief-in-pocket down the hall.  But if you want some food that tastes better, plain and simple, then stop by Red 8.

mzrzs_6iln0oSoEP-BvKxw.text: Really beautiful room, just like everything at Wynn.  Pretty standard Pan Asian menu with some fun drinks.  You definitely pay for the address but it's worth it to be at Wynn and it's cheaper than a lot of the other restaurants in the area.
